title: Error when using a subflow packaged as module with MQTT nodes
body: ### Current Behavior The `mqtt-in` node in a subflow packaged as module cannot find the `mqtt-broker` configuration node from the same packaged subflow. I get a "missing broker configuration" error in the debug window and Node-RED logs. The subflow works correctly when used "unpackaged" in the flow it was created in (presumably because it can find the "original" config node). Maybe related: https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/3798 https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/5249 ### Expected Behavior The `mqtt-in` node in in the packaged subflow can be pre-configured using a `mqtt-broker` configuration node in the same packaged subflow. That way the packaged subflow can be used without having to manually add a MQTT broker configuration node in the parent flow. ### Steps To Reproduce - Create a module with the example subflow `ecowatt.js` and `package.json` - Feel free to edit the broker URL, port, username, password... The goal of this node is to subscribe to a topic that should return a number (0/1/2/3), and when it changes it sends a message to the corresponding output and updates the status - Add the module to your Node-RED instance, you should see the node appear in the palette - Add the node to your flow and deploy it - You should see the "missing broker configuration" error ### Example flow #### Subflow content #### dist/nodes/ecowatt.js ```js const subflow = { "id": "0fe3ad82c97fd4f4", "type": "subflow", "name": "Current Ecowatt status", "info": "", "category": "network", "in": [], "out": [ { "x": 1110, "y": 160, "wires": [ { "id": "68ad2c483e9308cb", "port": 0 } ] }, { "x": 1110, "y": 260, "wires": [ { "id": "68ad2c483e9308cb", "port": 1 } ] }, { "x": 1120, "y": 360, "wires": [ { "id": "6d12729fb1f1cc3a", "port": 0 }, { "id": "fce93eec21ef785a", "port": 0 }, { "id": "dcead83c8741cad1", "port": 0 } ] }, "flow": [ { "id": "68ad2c483e9308cb", "type": "switch", "z": "0fe3ad82c97fd4f4", title: i18n: add Dutch (nl-NL) help documentation for core nodes
body:
## Summary

Add Dutch (nl-NL) translations for all 36 HTML help files that appear in the Info sidebar when a node is selected.

### Files translated:
- **common/** (9 files): inject, debug, catch, status, complete, link, comment, global-config, unknown
- **function/** (9 files): function, switch, change, range, template, delay, trigger, exec, rbe
- **network/** (8 files): mqtt, http-in/response/request, websocket, tcp, udp, tls, httpproxy
- **parsers/** (5 files): csv, html, json, xml, yaml
- **sequence/** (3 files): split/join, sort, batch
- **storage/** (2 files): file, watch

Follow-up to #5440 (editor-client) and #5442 (nodes/runtime messages).

## Test plan

- [x] Set language to Dutch (nl-NL) in Node-RED settings
- [x] Select various nodes and verify help text appears in Dutch in the Info sidebar

title: i18n: add Dutch (nl-NL) locale for editor-client
body:
## Summary

Adds complete Dutch (nl-NL) translation for the Node-RED editor. This is the first part of the Dutch locale contribution, focusing on the editor-client as recommended by @hardillb in #5439.

**Files added:**
- `editor.json` - Full translation of all editor UI strings (~1300 lines)
- `infotips.json` - Translation of 19 editor tips
- `jsonata.json` - Translation of JSONata function documentation

## Context

Many Node-RED users in the Netherlands and Belgium would benefit from a native language interface. This is especially relevant for Victron Energy customers, as Victron is a major Dutch company using Node-RED extensively in their ecosystem.

## Translation approach

- Technical terms like "node", "flow", "payload" are kept in English as they are standard terminology
- UI terms are translated naturally (e.g., "Settings" â†’ "Instellingen", "Deploy" â†’ "Deployen")
- Maintained i18next pluralization syntax (`_plural`, `__count__`)

## Test plan

- [x] Verified JSON syntax is valid
- [x] Editor UI displays Dutch text when nl-NL is selected

## Next steps

After this PR is reviewed, I plan to submit translations for core nodes.

Part of #5439

title: Feature Request: Dutch (nl-NL) locale translation
body:
## Summary

Would the Node-RED project be interested in a Dutch (nl-NL) locale translation?

## Context

A significant portion of the Node-RED user base in the energy/IoT sector is based in the Netherlands and Belgium. For example, many Victron Energy customers use Node-RED for their energy management systems, and these users are predominantly Dutch-speaking.

Currently available locales: de, en-US, es-ES, fr, ja, ko, pt-BR, ru, zh-CN, zh-TW

## Proposal

If there's interest, we would be willing to create and maintain a Dutch translation covering:
- editor-client (editor.json, infotips.json, jsonata.json)
- nodes (messages.json + HTML help files)
- runtime (runtime.json)

## Questions

1. Is a Dutch locale something the project would accept?
2. Are there specific translation guidelines or tools (Crowdin, Weblate, etc.) we should use?
3. Should we start with a partial translation (e.g., editor-client only) or aim for complete coverage?

Happy to contribute if this aligns with the project's goals.

---
Dennis Bosmans - Smart-e-Grid

title: fix: prevent uncaught exceptions in core node event handlers
body:
This PR adds try-catch blocks and null checks to event handlers in core nodes to prevent uncaught exceptions from crashing the Node-RED runtime.

## Problem

Several core nodes have event handlers (`on('data')`, `on('message')`, etc.) that process external data without try-catch protection. When malformed data or unexpected errors occur in these handlers, the exceptions propagate up and crash the entire Node-RED process.

## Solution

Added defensive error handling to the following nodes:

### TCP (`31-tcpin.js`)
- Wrapped all `on('data')` handlers in try-catch:
  - TcpIn client mode
  - TcpIn server mode
  - TcpGet request handler

### UDP (`32-udp.js`)
- Wrapped `on('message')` handler in try-catch

### Exec (`90-exec.js`)
- Wrapped stdout and stderr `on('data')` handlers in try-catch

### WebSocket (`22-websocket.js`)
- Wrapped `send()` loop in `handleEvent()` with try-catch

### MQTT (`10-mqtt.js`)
- Added null check for `packet` parameter in `subscriptionHandler()`
- Wrapped subscription handler callback in try-catch
- Added null check for `mpacket.properties`

## Impact

These changes ensure that errors in data processing are logged via `node.error()` instead of crashing the runtime. This improves stability when dealing with:
- Malformed network data
- Invalid encoding parameters
- Unexpected null/undefined values
- Errors in downstream processing

---

title: FR: UI notification when On Start or On Stop are modified (function node)
body:
**Background**
Node-RED function nodes have separate tabs for "On Start" and "On Stop" where you can add code to run once on start/stop. Very useful feature! For example, setting up context once, and leave room in normal code tab for msg handling. However, this is rarely used and easily forgotten. The way node red compartmentalizes code means you never see the whole picture at the same time.

**Problem**
Forgetting to check/update this can cause some issues. You may forget that it is there, misunderstand normal code or even copy-paste to make a new function node, getting unwanted code you're not aware of. People have reportedly manually added comments on line 1 in "On Message" to notify about On Start/Stop usage for years ðŸ˜„

**Solution**
Add some sort of notification to easily show user a function node has edited contents in On Start and/or On Stop tabs.
Not sure what is best here, but there may be several solutions:
- highlight the entire tab
- add a badge somewhere
- a hint (similar to inject node, that shows up on the right side of node name text area)

Either way, I think it would be best to check if code was added to a tab, not just modified. Because you may remove the default comments, (setting the text empty)  but still not want notification. At least no notification on empty text (in addition to default comments).

Discussion: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/notification-when-on-start-function-node-is-modified/100162

title: RED.import (importModule) cannot correctly handle aliased exports
body:
### Current Behavior

1. Say there's a module `M.js` in a package `pkg` that uses the `exports` section in `package.json` to alias/remap internal paths.
2. The `M.js` file is in the `pkg/dist` folder, but I put `pkg/M.js` as the "Module name" in a Node RED custom function
3. Node RED will report `Error: Cannot find module` at run-time
4. The "Require stack" will point to `$node_red_home/node_modules/pkg/M.js` which does not exist

### Expected Behavior

`require('pkg/M.js')` obviously work just fine from `node`, so should be supported by Node RED custom function import.

I believe [this line](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/80716cc45b3bb52a84af8065e5d1dea5be463a6a/packages/node_modules/@node-red/registry/lib/externalModules.js#L142) should reference `parsedModule.module`, so the `moduleDir` is always a real directory.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: affects all versions since RED.import was introduced
- Node.js version: 20
- npm version:
- Platform/OS:
- Browser:

title: API to show palette manager install tab with pre-populated search term is inconsistent
body:
### Current Behavior

When calling `RED.actions.invoke` to invoke the palette manager and select the "install" view and pre-populate the filter, it can sometimes be unreliable. 

1. if an editor is already open, the palette manager correctly replaces the editor in the tray, however the provided options are not applied
2. if the settings or global env vars are already open, the palette manager tab is not selected (the view is changed and the search term is populated, but the tab is not switched)
3. if the search window is open when it is executed, the search dropdown remains on screen (and becomes un-closable)

More details in https://github.com/FlowFuse/nr-assistant/pull/106 

### Expected Behavior

Invoking  the action should work consistently


### Steps To Reproduce

1. open any node settings
2. invoke `RED.actions.invoke('core:manage-palette', {view: 'install', filter: '"node-red-node-random"'})`1. 

--- 
1. open global env vars
2. invoke `RED.actions.invoke('core:manage-palette', {view: 'install', filter: '"node-red-node-random"'})`

---

1. open search dialog (CTRL-F)
2. invoke `RED.actions.invoke('core:manage-palette', {view: 'install', filter: '"node-red-node-random"'})`


### Example flow

```
paste your flow here
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.1.3
- Node.js version:

- Platform/OS:
- Browser: Chrome latest

title: FR: Import API to accept flows and option to bypass UI
body:
In the NR editor, the API `RED.clipboard.import` is the function used to import (and if necessary) show the import
conflicts dialog but, because `RED.clipboard.import` does not accept a "flow" parameter, it is not possible to use this for automation (like an AI agent)

Ideally, `RED.clipboard.import` would add support for passing in the `flow` JSON (or array) and have the option to bypass showing the UI (i.e. as if the user had pasted their flow and clicked the import button).  This would permit a helper/agent to perform an import while also seeing any conflicts and resolve them in the dialog (if required).

Lastly, I am pretty sure this would come with the above but we should check the existing `core:show-import-dialog` action also supports these new params.

More details in https://github.com/FlowFuse/nr-assistant/pull/106

title: TreeList: Fix arrow navigation through filtered TreeList
body:
## Types of changes

- [X] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Resolves https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/5430

EditableList hides filtered items with `.hide()`. Added a css display check when picking the next/previous sibling/child in the TreeList component. With this change, users should be able to navigate through the visible list. Went with this approach for the initial fix as it's a small code change.

Could alternatively:
- Make updates to have TreeList go through an actual filtered set of nodes so we don't have to do any checks like this.
- Add some kind of `isFiltered` flag to the items. Would prefer the above.

title: Add package-lock.json to mono-repo sub-packages for reproducible release builds
body:
## Context

PR #5426 added a root `package-lock.json` for the dev environment, but as noted in [this comment](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/pull/5426#issuecomment-3719601032), the mono-repo sub-packages still need their own lock files for reproducible release builds.

## Remaining Work

Generate `package-lock.json` for each sub-package:

- `@node-red/editor-api`
- `@node-red/editor-client`
- `@node-red/nodes`
- `@node-red/registry`
- `@node-red/runtime`
- `@node-red/util`
- `node-red`

Update the release build process to use `npm ci` for each package.

## Related

- Closes the remaining work from #5424
- Follow-up to #5426

As per discussion https://discourse.nodered.org/t/switch-node-pass-on-regexp-matches-with-the-msg/99936 this PR adds an option to the regex condition of the switch node to allow it to return the matches and match groups. It doesn't change the default behaviour or any other modes.

This does of course change the message passing though (by adding msg.matches property) - which is unlike any other switch option - so may not be desired though it doesn't affect any other options. Other alternatives mean adding extra nodes to either redo the extraction of groups or using a function node.

And adds tests for new option.

A deprecated package will be hidden from the list unless the search term matches the package identifier.

title: Add several click-outside-edit-tray behaviors
body:
## Types of changes

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Closes #5247.

Foreword: The purpose of that change was to prevent changes from being saved when clicking outside the edit tray and a poor revert is not enough to move forward... In theory, the changes should be discard, but in practice, users have their own preferences.

Revert the click-outside-edit-tray behavior to save changes and close the edit tray.

Also adds to the settings a selection input to allow the user to choose the desired behavior. The options and their behavior are as follows:

- `nothing`: do nothing
- `discard`: discard changes and close
- `save`: save changes and close

title: UX: Ensure menus handle vertical overflow
body: Our current menus (main menu, context menu) do not cope well if there is not enough vertical space to show them. If the bottom is off-screen, the options need to be scrollable so they can be accessed.

title: UX: replace touch radial menu with standard context menu

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
When using a touch screen with the editor, a touch-specific radial menu is shown when you long press on the workspace or a node.

We have since added our own custom right-click context menu to the workspace and are exposing an increasing number of things via it.

This task is to replace the radial menu with the context menu for a consistent UX.

Summary
 - `showTouchMenu` should call `RED.contextMenu.show(...)`
 - Remove `RED.touch.radialMenu`

Did a quick poc locally - some more event handling work is needed to make the context menu properly accessible to touch.

Also, need to check what options are exposed on the radialMenu to ensure equivalent functionality is available on the context menu. For example, edit/undo/redo. This does risk making the context menu huge...

title: Demote deprecated packages in the install list
body:
We now have the ability to mark packages as deprecated. This flag is not currently being taken into account when sorting the palette manager results. In one specific case, `node-red-dashboard` is still coming top of the list (due to its high download stats), but is marked as deprecated.

We should de-prioritise deprecated nodes. I'm not sure hiding them entirely is a good idea - there are reasons a user may need to continue using a deprecated node until they can invest time to migrate. A quick win would be to ensure they appear at the bottom of the search results.

title: NR5: Node Appearance improvements
body:
As part of the Node-RED 5.0 UX modernization, we're looking at what improvements can be made to the node (and flow) appearance within the editor.

The design of the node has changed very little since the early days of the project. Over time, various additions have been made (status text below, badges above). But there are some unsatisfied requirements we want to look at.

 - Visualisation of 'virtual' wires - eg Link Call, Status, Catch nodes
 - Standard way for extending the node appearance. Some nodes, eg image-tools, insert additional UI components in the canvas.

At this stage, there are no concrete proposals, but this issue is where we'll focus activity.

title: NR5: Project Infrastructure Updates
body:
This issue covers a number of infrastructure-oriented tasks we want to complete as part of the overall modernisation of the Node-RED developer UX. This is focussed on ensuring the code base is approachable and easy to contribute to.


 - Apply standard linting to code base.
 - Reword repo structure to use npm workspaces
 - Move to modern task runner

There are four threads of activity for Node-RED 5. Some are more well-defined than others. Each thread has its own parent issue linked below.

The intention is to ship early and ship often for Node-RED 5.0. We will do regular beta releases, starting asap, so we can more easily get feedback from the community. We can evaluate the reach of the beta via the telemetry feedback.

title: Fix CORS preflight OPTIONS to respect PATCH in httpNodeCors
body:
### Summary
This PR fixes an issue where Node-RED's admin API did not respect the user-provided
`httpNodeCors.methods` list when handling OPTIONS preflight requests. PATCH was not being
recognized, causing CORS failures when users exposed HTTP In nodes expecting PATCH requests.

### What this PR does
- Reads `settings.httpNodeCors.methods`
- Ensures PATCH is included if user configured it
- Applies unified CORS handler before other admin middleware
- Avoids relying on hardcoded "GET,PUT,POST,DELETE"
- Prevents redeclaration collisions with existing corsHandler

### Why this matters
Modern APIs use PATCH heavily. Users who configured PATCH in their runtime settings still
experienced failed preflight requests. This PR ensures Node-RED respects runtime configuration
as intended.

### Testing
- Verified with a local development build of Node-RED (npm run dev)
- Confirmed OPTIONS requests return 200 with correct Access-Control-Allow-Methods including PATCH
- Confirmed no regressions for GET/PUT/POST/DELETE

Thank you for reviewing!

title: OPTIONS requests always return hardcoded CORS headers, breaking PATCH preflight
body:
### Current Behavior

All HTTP requests sent to "http in" endpoints with the OPTIONS method are intercepted and always return the following generic CORS headers:

```
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: GET,PUT,POST,DELETE
```

This behavior breaks CORS handling for PATCH requests: when the browser performs the preflight check, the response does not include "PATCH" in the allowed methods, causing the request to fail.

All other HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) correctly return the methods configured in `httpNodeCors` inside `settings.js.`

### Expected Behavior

The OPTIONS handler should respect the configuration provided in httpNodeCors and return all allowed methods, including "PATCH" if it is defined.

No hardcoded CORS headers should override or bypass the user-defined CORS configuration.

Preflight requests should succeed whenever the configured CORS rules allow the incoming method.

### Steps To Reproduce

Use any HTTP client (e.g., Postman, curl, or a browser) to call an http in endpoint with a standard method `(GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH)`.
The CORS response reflects the configuration defined in httpNodeCors.

Make a request to the same endpoint using the `OPTIONS` method (typically triggered by browsers during CORS preflight).
The response returns a hardcoded CORS configuration:

```
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: GET,PUT,POST,DELETE
```

Notice that "PATCH" is missing from the allowed methods, even if it is configured in httpNodeCors.

### Example flow

```
paste your flow here
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: latest

title: Shared configuration selector defaults to "none" even if valid config node exists
body:
For reference - discussed here: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/did-the-config-select-dropdown-behaviour-change/99693

### Current Behavior

With any collection that uses a common configuration node, that configuration node is not selected by default when creating new nodes on the palette.  Instead, the value "none" is the default which requires selecting the valid config, saving the node, and reopening of the node for the config to "take effect".

### Expected Behavior

When a valid and/or already in use configuration node exists for a specific collection, creating a new node on the palette from the same collection should default to using that config node and not "none".

### Steps To Reproduce

Using collection "node-red-contrib-musiccast".

1. Drag node onto palette from sidebar.   Open node and UI is displayed that allows for selecting a config node.  Config node is set to "none".
2. Click + to create a new config node and save.  Close config node.
3. Close "chilld" node and reopen to apply/use new config.  
4. Create new node on palette.   Config selector again defaults to "none".   Config node has to be selected, node closed and reopened.

### Example flow

Too complicated but behavior has been observed on all node collections or nodes that use a common config node.


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.1.0
- Node.js version: 22.11
- npm version: 10.9
- Platform/OS: Linux/Docker/Synology NAS   and MacOS
- Browser:  Safari/Brave

title: Switch node: `stopping after first match` should be default, not `checking all rules`
body:
### Current Behavior

A new switch node dragged into a project is set to `checking all rules` by default.

### Expected Behavior

Considering the node is called a `switch` and _not_ a `router`, the default for this option should be changed. I'd hazard it's the more common use as well. Considering the many bugs this misleading default surely causes for newer users, I consider it a small bug.

- npm version:

title: Switch node: `otherwise` does not live up to its name
body:
### Current Behavior

`otherwise` in English signifies a strong `else` case functionality, but this value does not work like that at all. In fact, since the switch filters are parsed only ever in order from top to bottom, an `else` case is actually impossible, which is unfortunate. In light of this fact, this switch filter name must be changed to reflect its true function semantically.

### Expected Behavior

Either a true `else` case should ideally be added to the switch node, whereby all the filter options are parsed first to see if present. This could be called `else` and live in the first slot, something currently impossible in Node-RED's switch node.

Either way, the name of `otherwise` must be changed, as it's highly misleading and leads to catastrophic dataflow user error. I'm open to the new name as long as it accurately reflects its function:
- `If no prior match`
- `default if no prior match`
- or even just `default`

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.1.0
- Node.js version:
- npm version:
- Platform/OS:
- Browser:

title: Editor: Change- deploy - undo - deploy fails to mark dirty badges & activate `Deploy` button
body:
### Current Behavior

This appears to be a flaw in the deploy point creation or detection engine whereby _two_ flows states are both treated as the current deployment state. Also, node dirty markers don't seem to appear at all when using the undo history.

### Expected Behavior

- Dirty markers on nodes (blue disc) should reappear during the entire undo/redo process if said node differs from live flows state.
- Deploying then redoing should never grey out the Deploy button.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Open an extant install (with stuff on it) and deploy.
2. Add some stuff to flow and deploy again.
3. Undo the actions from step 2, and deploy a third time.
4. Redo up the actions from step 2 and notice the Deploy button greys out again even though the live Editor state does not match the active Deploy state anymore.

simple to reproduce

title: Introduce `Graceful Shutdown`
body: ## Types of changes - [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ## Proposed changes Introduce a graceful period in shutdown process to prevent interrupting in-progress processes. Rework of the excellent work done in #2296 by @k-toumura. This PR contains an updated implementation and a more extensive concept. See key differences. ### Definitions - `Message Initiator Nodes`: any node that triggers the sending of a message outside of the processing of an incoming message. - `Shutdown Scope`: any flow capable of receiving a message through the link and subflow nodes for the same workflow. So, if flow A contains an `inject` node and a `link out` node, flow B contains a `link in` node and a `link out` node, and flow C contains a `link in` node and a `debug` node, the scope will be A, B, and C because the workflow will traverse all three flows. - `failFast`: cancels graceful shutdown of other flows in the scope. In other words, it forces the shutdown of all nodes of other flows in the scope. ### Concept Currently, when a flow closes, all nodes are closed in a single-step sequence. With *Graceful Shutdown*, there are **three** steps in the shutdown sequence: 1. Close all message initiator nodes 2. Wait in-progress messages 3. Close remaining nodes #### Message initiator nodes These nodes are defined by the user in the UI. Each flow and subflow contains a new pane that allows the user to choose these nodes. >[!WARNING] > We assume that a message initiator node must have an output and cannot be a link node (it transmits a message, it does not create one). #### In-progress messages Each flow contains a message counter. This counter is incremented when a node sends a message and decremented when a node receives a message. Step 2 will end when the counter reaches 0 or when the timeout is exceeded. The counter works for a single flow as follows: ![single-flow-shutdown](https://github.com/node-red-hitachi/designs/raw/graceful-shutdown/designs/graceful-shutdown/sequence.svg) If the scope is the flow itself, the counter is that of the flow. Otherwise, the counter is the sum of the counters that make up the scope. The counter works for a multiple flows as follows: ![multiple-flows-shutdown](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/61d6f2fd-5e47-435c-8f5a-ceaa378b389f) Each flow can have its own timeout, but the flow's configuration will affect this. If a flow simply forwards the message to the next flow, it may be wanted to close it once the message has been sent. #### `failFast` If a flow fails to close in time (timeout exceeded), it can force the shutdown of other flows in the scope that are in shutdown phase. #### flow/node change deployment The sequence is identical, but the calculation in step 2 is based on "is one of the nodes I'm stopping waiting for a message?" . We can't use the counter here because other nodes are active. Therefore, we must try to find a point at which nodes we're stopping are no longer receiving messages. ### Key differences - Support for messages crossing a flow (link or subflow node) - Simulated Node Messaging API - Timeout per flow - Cancel other flow if this one fails - Support for flow/node change deployment ### Limitations - An asynchronous job must call `done()` itself, otherwise the counter may be inaccurate (offset). e.g. `function` node. - Any loop, whatever its nature, is unmanageable. ### Related links - Originel design: https://github.com/node-red-hitachi/designs/blob/graceful-shutdown/designs/graceful-shutdown/README.md - Originel implementation: https://github.com/node-red/node-red/pull/2296 ### Test flow ```json title: Cannot save the code to the library from the function node property UI without expanding the folder
body: ### Current Behavior When trying to save code to the focused function folder after selecting "Save to Library..." in the function node property UI, Node-RED users cannot save the code when the folder isn't expanded. On the other hand, they can save code when folder is expanded. This issue also occurs with the Template node. ### Expected Behavior Even if the folder isn't expanded manually, Node-RED users can save the code to the focused folder. In the "Export nodes" dialog, they can save flow without expanding the folder operations. I would like to apply the same behavior. ### Steps To Reproduce 1. Place a function node in the flow. 2. Open the function node properties UI 3. Select "Save to Library..." 4. Click "Save" ### Example flow ### Environment - Node-RED version: v4.1.1 - Node.js version: v24.4.1 - npm version: v11.4.2 - Platform/OS: Ubuntu on WSL2 in Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2 - Browser: Microsoft Edge 142.0.3595.53 (64 bit)

title: UX: Make workspace scrollable in all directions

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
Currently we have a fixed size workspace that is anchored in the top-left corner.

If a user wants to expand their flow above, or to the right, of what they currently have, they have to move everything to make space. In many other canvas-based apps, the workspace is centered, allowing for expansion in any direction.

The purpose of this issue is to examine how to achieve a similar result in Node-RED.

There are a number of items to consider:

1. Having the flows anchored in the top-left corner makes it easy to scroll to the start - you hit a wall and can't overshoot. If the flows are now in the middle of the workspace, we need a way for the user to get back to a 'home' position easily
2. The existing view of a flow on load shouldn't change. All existing flows are anchored at 0,0 - if the default view becomes 2500,2500 then their flows aren't shown. The suggests we keep 0,0 as the default top-left corner shown on load, but allow the scroll into -ve values. That will then mean nodes have -ve coordinates - if such a flow is exported and reimported in older NR version, those nodes will be 'lost' to the user as they can't scroll to see them. I'm not sure if we have a clean way to address that and may just be an accepted cost of this change.


Some UX thoughts:

 - The view navigator can be used to help a user anchor where they are. This was part of the motivation in #5312 to temporarily show the navigator whenever the user pans/scrolls. I've disabled that feature in 5312 to unblock the rest of the changes, but we'd look at restoring that behaviour for this.
 - The 'zoom to fit' option added via #5312 would get them back to their flows, albeit it zoomed.
 - Feels like we'd want a way to have a one-click 'home' button. That's making the set of zoom buttons quite extensive - so a rethink there perhaps to slim down the footprint of the controls.

title: Add `node actions` to the context menu
Introduces the `ephemeral` status and `duration` option
body:
## Types of changes

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Introduces the `ephemeral` status and `duration` option.

### Ephemeral Concept

An *ephemeral* status is a purely visual status; it has no role in the runtime (it does not trigger a `Status` node).

This status is defined by adding the `ephemeral=true` property. Optionally, the `duration` property allows to override the default duration of `5s`.

At the end of the duration, the old retained status will be restored or cleared if no status is available.

#### Editor

- The minimum duration is set to `100 ms`
- If an ephemeral status is in progress and another status arrives (ephemeral or not) it will replace the status with its associated behavior.
- The displayed text is in italics to recognize an ephemeral status

#### Runtime

- When an ephemeral status arrives at `handleStatus`, this status will only trigger the `node-status` event.
- `Status` nodes will not be triggered.
- Duration is not handled in the runtime when it is an ephemeral status.

### Duration Concept

Duration on *default* status allows it to be cleared at the end of the duration.

#### Editor

- The minimum duration is set to `100 ms`
- If a status is in progress and another status arrives (ephemeral or not) it will replace the status with its associated behavior.

### Runtime

- The duration must be greater than `0`.
- When duration is set, it will call `handleStatus` back at the end of duration to clear the status.
- Clearing status is handled in the editor.

## Typing

```ts
interface NodeStatus {
  fill?: NodeStatusFill;
  shape?: NodeStatusShape;
  text?: string;
  duration?: number;
  ephemeral: boolean;
}
```

## Related Issue(s)

- https://discourse.nodered.org/t/support-for-node-status-list-and-duration/97735

## Todo list

- [ ] Italic text
- [ ] Update docs
- [ ] Update Monaco/ACE editors
- [ ] Add unit tests

## Test Flow

title: WIP: Allow `catch` node to catch any error from any node
body:
## Types of changes

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Allow `catch` node to catch any error other than message processing and to catch errors from config nodes.

### Concept

Each `catch` node can select one or more config nodes from the same scope or from the global scope.

#### Editor:

- `all`
  - show a new checkbox to enable `anyError` (allow any error other than message processing) [^1]
  - show a new checkbox to enable `includeConfig` (allow to catch errors from config nodes from the same scope and from the global scope)
- `group`
  - keep the actual behavior
- `target`
  - show a new checkbox to enable `anyError` (allow any error other than message processing) [^1]
  - show a new checkbox to enable `includeConfig` (allow to catch errors from config nodes from the same scope or from the global scope)
    - the `treeList` will contain two tabs (the current flow and the global flow)
    - config nodes will be included there with an `fa-cog` icon

#### Runtime:

- `flow.handleError` will be called if the message is:
  - an `object`
  - `undefined`
- catch nodes will be triggered if:
  - `msg` exists (actual behavior)
  - `msg` does not exist and `anyError` is enabled
- propagate Error events from global config nodes to any nodes using this config node
  - will not be called if the scope contains the config node or the scope is `all`
### Limitations

- the *select nodes* functionality does not exist for config nodes

### Related Issue(s)

- https://discourse.nodered.org/t/extend-the-catch-node-to-errors-not-triggered-by-message-processing/99336

### Todo list

- [x] Finds out how to trigger `catch` nodes when errors comes from any global config node (`Flow` instance does not have access to `activeFlows`
- [ ] Update node docs
- [ ] Adapt/update core nodes
- [ ] Add unit tests

## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

[^1]: Of course if a config node is selected but the `anyError` option is disabled, the error will not be caught

title: Delay node treats flush command with _event as new message
body:
### Current Behavior

This applies to the built-in delay node.
Versions: 4.1.1 & 4.1.0 (possibly other versions too)
Node: 22

Delay node (used as queue) supports command messages like { flush: 1} or { reset: 1}.

However, when using function node to generate these command messages, additional meta data like _msgid is added automagically. If also using for example link in/out nodes for wiring back, the prop _event is added. With command message like { flush: 1, _msgid: "*UUID*", _event: "blahblah" }, this will trigger flush command as normal, but additionally also output this message from the queue! So it generates a unexpected ghost message. This doesn't seem to happen with reset commands, only flush (with _event prop).

Steps to reproduce:

1) Generate flush command {flush: 1}
2) send via link in/out so that _event is added
3) send to delay node
4) delay node outputs unexpected message { _msgid: "*UUID*", _event: "blahblah" }

Identifying this cause in a complicated flow was not easy.

Expected result: Command messages should not be forwarded to output as regular message in queue just because it includes meta data (in the example I found it was _event). Not sure if other commands are affected. Reset command seems to behave correctly even with _event prop.

### Expected Behavior

_No response_

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Example flow

```
paste your flow here
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version:
- Node.js version:
- npm version:
- Platform/OS:
- Browser:

title: Restore tab order from last session
body:
## Types of changes

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Ref: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/editor-save-tabs-display-and-order-between-web-page-loads/99486

Restore tab order from last session. This also includes subflows, they will be opened and ordered.

The local storage name is `tabOrder` and it's an array.

Notes:
- There is no filter mechanism every time the editor is loaded because the reorder overwrites the array.
- The order of the last session will not be applied if a current tab is not there; to avoid a session that is too old.

## Checklist

title: Editor sidebar: Subflows display with wrong number of ports
body:
### Current Behavior

In the node picker sidebar, all subflows display with exactly one input and one output port, even if the subflow has a different number. This is confusing and misleading UX.

### Expected Behavior

Ideally, subflows should display with the correct number of I/O ports.

If that's too difficult or process-intensive, it would be preferable to display them with no ports at all to avoid the erroneous display.

### Steps To Reproduce

Create a subflow with a different amount of I/O ports than 1/1 and look at its representation in the sidebar.

### Example flow

simple to reproduce


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.1.0
- Node.js version:
- npm version:
- Platform/OS: macOS
- Browser: Chrome

title: UX: Sidebar UX improvements

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body: There are various problem statements related to the sidebar UX in the editor. - The Node-RED editor has the Palette on the left, and the sidebar on the right. The RH sidebar becomes a catch-all container for all other sidebars. This can make it hard to find information as so much is stacked in the one sidebar. - The Info sidebar provides an overview of all of your flows. Having it on the RH side doesn't feel natural in a left-to-right information hierarchy - Users want to see their Debug information at the same time as navigating other information in the sidebars. Currently they cannot do two things at once. There are a number of UX proposals around tackling these problems. 1. Move the Info sidebar over to the left side - share the space with the Palette. Image here is a working mockup, but not the complete story... 2. Provide a way to show the debug sidebar at the same time as other sidebars Before getting into the finer details of any of these items, there is a common need to have more flexibility in how/where the sidebars are shown. As a first step in towards this, the tasks for this issue are: 1. Reimplement the Palette component as a Sidebar component. 2. Have a sidebar container on both the LH and RH sides of the workspace 3. Update the sidebar API to allow a pane to 'pick' a target side. The net result should be largely the same layout we have today, but the underlying architecture has more flexibility. Following steps will include: - a refresh of how the sidebar tabs/buttons work to be more intuitive and discoverable - allow a sidebar to be vertically split - so different sidebars can be shown top/bottom

title: Subflow instance edit UI: Property keys column doesn't expand width to string length
body:
### Current Behavior

Currently, on my client if a subflow property name exceeds about 12 uppercase characters, the rest of the name is cut off by the value column. Unlike the property-setting UI, this column does not expand if one drags the properties slideout width larger, which means the subflow property name _cannot be read_ in its entirety in the Editor.

### Expected Behavior

Similar to the property creation slideout, when the width of the slideout is increased, both columns expand their widths. 

Ideally, the styling would actually also load the slideout with the column already set to display the entire maximum property name width (up to a maximum of, say, 50% width).

I also just noticed that the styling is duplicated on the subflow template UI Preview tab, so all of this applies to that view as well.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create a subflow with 1+ properties with long names and whatever values.

title: Fix dropped statuses when resolving missing types
body:
## Types of changes

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

If a user installs a module that resolves missing types, previously stopped flows will start before the editor is notified of the added types. Therefore, statuses published before the editor loads the definitions will be dropped.

The bug occurs when the editor receives a status but the node at that time is still of type `unknown`, which causes an error because i18n (`node._`) does not exist on these nodes. Replacing the node definition fails and the status is dropped.

To resolve this bug, I propose ignoring the status if i18n is not available and also republishing statuses when the module installation is complete (after the editor is notified of the added types).

## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [ ] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Node-RED UX Modernisation
body: As a result of the recent community survey, we are embarking on a project to bring some modernisation to the overall Node-RED UX. This is an ongoing piece of work that we'll approach iteratively. This epic issue is a placeholder to help organise the sub issues that will get raised out of this. The following screenshot is a mockup of the type of thing we're considering. **This is not a committed design.**

title: FR: Handle nodes contained in dependencies
body:
NR has a known limitation related to nodes contained in dependencies, and I would like to propose a draft design that would solve the most common case (in my opinion).

## Problem

I'll use my own case.

My module contains three nodes and one dependency. This dependency contains one config node.

If I install my palette from the Palette Manager, I have to restart NR to load all nodes otherwise only the three nodes are loaded by NR.

My `package.json`:

```json
"node-red": {
  "nodes": {
    "firestore-out": "build/nodes/firestore-out.js",
    "firestore-in": "build/nodes/firestore-in.js",
    "firestore-get": "build/nodes/firestore-get.js"
  }
},
"dependencies": {
  "@gogovega/firebase-config-node": "~0.3.1"
}
```

## Technical Reason

- NR scans the `node_modules` folder to a single depth
  - This explains why restarting NR loads all my nodes
- When installing from Palette Manager, the registry will only load the package whose module matches
  - This explains why the config node is not loaded

## Design Proposal

#2770 introduced the `dependencies` property, which is a list of dependencies that the registry must load.

Something like:

```json
"node-red": {
  "nodes": {
    "firestore-out": "build/nodes/firestore-out.js",
    "firestore-in": "build/nodes/firestore-in.js",
    "firestore-get": "build/nodes/firestore-get.js"
  },
  "dependencies": [
    "@gogovega/firebase-config-node"
  ]
},
"dependencies": {
  "@gogovega/firebase-config-node": "~0.3.1"
}
```

This is perfect, it's what I'm looking for. BUT... nodes contained in these dependencies are **runtime-only**.

![my-reaction](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/71f9fbd4-2aea-4a96-801d-7f1c9d2f8d99)

I therefore propose:

1. If the parent module (at the top) is a Subflow, dependencies will be runtime-only.
2. Modify the `dependencies` property to be an object and set what should be runtime-only. Problem: Handle overwrites...

## Constraints

### NPM

In most cases, NPM will install my two modules in the first depth, but sometimes NPM installs the dependency in my first module directory. In this case, NPM will not be able to load that module.

So:

```txt
[userDir]/node_modules/@gogovega/firebase-config-node
[userDir]/node_modules/@gogovega/node-red-contrib-cloud-firestore

VS

[userDir]/node_modules/@gogovega/node-red-contrib-cloud-firestore
[userDir]/node_modules/@gogovega/node-red-contrib-cloud-firestore/node_modules/@gogovega/firebase-config-node
```

The solution would be to search in the first depth, and if the module is not found, search in the module that defined this dependency. If the module is still not found, the module will be considered missing.

Of course, since there is no version control it is up to the node developer to handle it. In case the *wrong* module is loaded; the module exists in the first and second depth.

### Palette Manager

Need to update the palette to avoid removing a module if its dependencies are still in use or adapt what will be removed (this logic already exists on the runtime side).

### Scan Depth

Only the first depth should be fully scanned (actual behavior), then modules with dependencies will trigger another logic that will search only for these modules. This avoids another scan.


Do not hesitate to ask me for clarification on any points you do not understand ðŸ˜‰

title: Fix `onremove` is not called on a pure editor plugin
body:
## Types of changes

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

The `onremove` method is not called on a plugin that exists only in the editor.

If `set.plugins` is empty, the plugin has no part in the runtime.

## Checklist

title: Fix: Avoid communication queue overflow with warning and throttling mechanâ€¦
body:
## Types of changes

What types of changes does your code introduce?
Put an `x` in the boxes that apply

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] ~~New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)~~

## Proposed changes

If debug nodes or status updates from nodes are used extensively, messages accumulate in the `CommsConnection`.
It holds a queue to which the messages get appended.
The logic for sending up to 50 messages every 50ms leads to excessive memory usage if the UI is opened by a user and messages are arriving faster than every 1ms which is often the case for high-volume data processing where one may receive thousands of updates per second if users forgot to disable/properly manage debug nodes.
This may result in system instability and also makes debugging the issue hard as the "suspected memory leak" only shows when the UI is opened somewhere.

A missing discard of pending messages on disconnect also leads to a slow decline of memory usage because of 1 message/ms being handled.

The proposed changes introduce the following:
- Cap the message queue size at 10,000
- If the limit is exceeded, log a warning to the server log and immediately to the UI log
- Drop new messages
- Overflow warnings use a cooldown of 30 seconds before firing again.

Although this is not a clean solution, this fixes the problem with system instability.

In the future, better detection of the actual sources/culprits may be introduced for improved feedback and to avoid the hard drop of messages.

## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] ~~I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality~~

title: (Palette Manager): Allow update from the `install` tab
body:
## Types of changes

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

To avoid confusion between current and next versions, this PR adds an `Update` button to the `Install` tab of the Palette Manager.

If the palette is not installed, the active button is `install`.
If the palette is installed:
- and up-to-date - `installed`
- update possible (and allowed) - `update`
- updated - `updated`

The `update` function has been modified to accept `entry.id` as `name` because `entry.name` is not always defined.

Forum discussion: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/update-notification-in-manage-palette/99128

## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)

title: Wire Junctions: Visual loop shapes interrupt visual clarity on right-to-left wire paths
body:
### Current Behavior

Whenever I place a wire junction and the second wire reverses direction (i.e, goes letfward), the displayed wire path usually creates a visual loop. The loops are visually confusing, make wire tracing hard, and don't seem necessary. Some RTL wire junctions don't have a loop, but drag them up and down and loops form. Imo this is a logic flaw in the wire junction display algorithm.

### Expected Behavior

Why not just curve the wire without crossing over itself? It's certainly possible from a visual standpoint. Is it an intentional choice to distinguish that the overall wire is heading right to left or something? If so, it's inconsistent and therefore useless anyways. But I would expect no loops since they're not visually required to connect the 2 wire segments.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create two nodes aligned horizontally.
2. Wire the output of the right node to input of the left. Notice no loop in the wire.
3. Add a junction to this wire.
4. Observe that the wire path around the junction forms a loop. There is no visual necessity for this loop to exist per se.

### Example flow

simple example above

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.1.0
- Node.js version: 22.19.0
- npm version: 10.9.3
- Platform/OS: Ubuntu
- Browser: Chrome

title: Add "Subflow" options to the right-click context menu
body:
Currently the "Subflow" options for "Create Subflow" and "Selection to Subflow" are nested in the top-right menu. I often find myself selecting nodes and then right-clicking to move them to a subflow, but alas, this option isn't present.

Instead, I need to highlight the nodes, then select the top-right menu and navigate to the "Subflow" submenu.

This would be most appropriate for "Selection to Subflow", and arguably, is the only relevant option here to add to a right-click menu, as "Create Subflow" wouldn't have too much value.

title: Websocket node not using proxy settings

Proxy should be used

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Configure a proxy via environment variable (ws_proxy or wss_proxy)

3. check if the proxy is used for the connection

title: Nodered v4.0.9 crashes when device storage is full
body:
**Steps =>**
1) install nodered ( used a dockerized version ) and start a flow
2) increase device's storage and make it 100% full
dd if=/dev/zero of=/persistent/80percent_filled_file bs=<give_necessary_size>M count=1 status=progress

**Observation =>**
nodered crashes and server restarts

**Expectation =>**
Is there any way an error in the UI can be thrown that the storage is full ?
or any other mechanism using which a crash can be avoided ?

title: Set default shortcut for editor dialog cancelation to escape (or other)
body:
Following improvements to Monaco escape key improvements in #5200 we can set the default shortcut of `CTRL-ESC` to `ESC` for edit dialog cancellation. 

This will remove the need for every windows user to remap the default shortcut for edit dialog cancel (CTRL+ESC is the start menu shortcut and cannot be overridden by a browser)

Alternatively, pick some default that windows user can use (`CTRL-Q` or `ALT-X` or ...)

title: Improve edit dialog escape situation
body:
Ideally, we could follow conventions and simply esc from the dialog to cancel changes but as Nicks points out, `esc` inside Monaco editor is a common action. To resolve this, we may wish to ensure the ESCkey does not bubble up from the Monaco editor. > I would like to strongly urge us to also consider changing the default shortcut for cancelling the edit dialog to just ESC > > As it stands, the browser is not permitted to capture the current default shortcut CTRL+ESC because it is dedicated to the Windows Start menu: > > Current Default: > > > Results in this: > ![RYEgFxWpNa](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6c28647d-b196-4c7d-a886-52033bf50a77) > >
> > I dont consider this request to be feature creep - as I feel it goes hand in hand with the whole UX this FR PR is concerned with, its just that the OP is likely not an MS Win user so did not spot this. However, if it is desired, I can raise a separate FR for changing the default edit close shortcut? _Originally posted by @Steve-Mcl in https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/5122#issuecomment-2959832061_ > as noted in previous discussions, we had complaints about using `escape` because that key gets used a lot in monaco to make all its popups go away. Muscle memory can then lead to losing all your work - and its very unforgiving. So no, we won't make that change unless there's a way to suppress the NR keyboard handling whilst monaco has focus. _Originally posted by @knolleary in https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/5122#issuecomment-3004902173_

title: Allow port appearance to vary if connected
body:
Closes #5092 

This PR extracts the parts of #3318 related to the port appearance - and fixes some bits around input port handling.

Now, any port with a wire connected to it has a class of `.red-ui-flow-port-connected`. This will allow us to style connected and disconnected ports differently.

*But* I don't have a good proposal for what that difference in appearance should be. In #3318 the changes were a bit more drastic - moving the ports behind the node body. I'm less keen on that now. But getting this PR raised as a draft to build on later.

title: Feature: add context menu item to jump to link call target node
body:
Original discussion: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/direct-navigation-from-link-call-node-to-definition-node/96802/

Having a way to quickly navigate to a Link Call node's target Link In has been an often requested feature. But it has always stalled at what the UI should be around the node to enable it.

The proposal from the discussion above is a simple solution to add a Context Menu item to do just that - so a user can right-click on the node and select the option. It isn't a one-click solution, but it's better then the lack of solution we have today.

Ideally we don't want to hard code this into the editor; other nodes may have legitimate actions to surface in the menu.

The proposal is then:

1. Allow a node to register custom menu items in their definition
2. When showing the context menu, include the node-specific actions
3. Update the Link Call node to register the 'jump to target' action
4. Check if any other core nodes have similar 'obvious' actions to add

When registering the menu items, the item will need:
 - label
 - action - either a callback function, or a string name of a registered action (check the naming conventions of existing code)

title: Node must not be considered Dirty when its State changes from A->B->A
body:
### Current Behavior

After changing a node from state A to state B and then back to state A, the node is still marked as dirty when it is not. This causes unecessary deployments.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4441e9e0-d8e0-4fde-8ca7-36d08d993f75


### Expected Behavior

Node must not be considered Dirty when its State changes from A->B->A.
To compute the dirty state of a node Node-RED must consider changes diffing against the node's initial state, which is set when the page is first served. After clicking on the Deploy button, the initial state is reset.

1. drag and drop a function node into the canvas
2. double click on this function node
3. set the function node's code to something random like

title: Setting servername or ALPN in the TLS config node for http-request causes error
body:
### Current Behavior

If a http-request node is configured with a TLS node that includes either a `servername` or a ALPN entry then the http-request fails with error messages.

This appears to be because of field name enforcement by the GOT library (typescript).

There is an open feature request for supporting `servername` for SNI here:

https://github.com/sindresorhus/got/issues/2320

for ALPN it should just be a case of remapping the case of the field name

raised on NR Slack https://node-red.slack.com/archives/C0LBBMNRY/p1744481081269069

>Hi, I think this has something to do with node-red version though not 100% sure, anyway few releases between working and broken state but no flow/config changes.
No idea which version worked but with latest I got errors from GOT when using HTTP request node:
"HTTPS option `ALPNProtocols` does not exist" if trying to use ALPN and "HTTPS option `servername` does not exist" if trying to add SNI/server name.
Anyone has idea what's wrong / if this is node-red issue which version did break it? I bet some are using these for something, maybe with some mTLS connections, just getting SNI right with nonstandard HTTPS port or maybe to negotiate h2/h3 connection. So would be interesting to hear if someone is currently using these without issues (4.0.9)?

### Expected Behavior
not throw errors

### Steps To Reproduce
create http-requst
add tls node
enter server name
trigger request

title: Join node leaking memory (the way I'm using it)
body:
### Current Behavior

Hello,

This week Iâ€™ve been investigating a memory leak in one of the Node-RED projects I maintain. After some debugging, I was able to isolate the issue to the `join` node, or more precisely, to the way I'm using it.

In my case, the `join` node was configured in _manual_ mode to synchronize two asynchronous events by merging their payloads into a single object.

The problem occurs when one of the two events happens very frequently (e.g., once per second), while the other occurs only rarely (e.g., once a week). In this setup, the frequent input causes the `join` node to accumulate `done()` callbacks while waiting for the second input. Over time, this leads to a memory leak.

This is the line that causes the callbacks accumulation: [https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/23c44db30d0a97ca4ae86a4e56627272a0f8723b/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/sequence/17-split.js#L745](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/23c44db30d0a97ca4ae86a4e56627272a0f8723b/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/sequence/17-split.js#L745)

### Expected Behavior

I'm expecting the `join` node to handle multiple messages with the same key by dropping outdated data, without leaking memory over time. I havenâ€™t had time to go through the code in detail, but I believe there should be a way to clean up previously stored callbacks associated with the same key.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Example flow

```
[{"id":"fb6caddf2d62ae38","type":"tab","label":"Example","disabled":false,"info":"","env":[]},{"id":"fd21f58f482c768c","type":"join","z":"fb6caddf2d62ae38","name":"","mode":"custom","build":"object","property":"payload","propertyType":"msg","key":"topic","joiner":"\\n","joinerType":"str","accumulate":false,"timeout":"","count":"2","reduceRight":false,"reduceExp":"","reduceInit":"","reduceInitType":"","reduceFixup":"","x":550,"y":180,"wires":[[]]},{"id":"abfd96f5aeabb27c","type":"inject","z":"fb6caddf2d62ae38","name":"Event # 1 (occurring every second)","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"1","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"event1","payload":"{\"a\":1,\"b\":2,\"c\":3,\"d\":4,\"e\":5}","payloadType":"json","x":250,"y":120,"wires":[["fd21f58f482c768c"]]},{"id":"a4bd231156d1a46f","type":"inject","z":"fb6caddf2d62ae38","name":"Event # 2 (occurring once in a while)","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"604800","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"event2","payload":"{\"f\":1,\"g\":2}","payloadType":"json","x":250,"y":240,"wires":[["fd21f58f482c768c"]]}]
```

title: Bigint parsing and handling
body:
### Background
Bigint has been around since ~2020 and JSON still does not parse it.  This means we cannot easily pass objects with these values over MQTT. 


### Experience
Recently, I was working with a new OPC-UA node which outputs Bigint values.  The aim was to send the OPC data to MQTT (essentially a basic and straightforward OPC-MQTT gateway) however without some custom JS code I was unable to send the object.

### Demo
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ba1f3284-6d57-4f4a-a9bb-c9d4aa71e443)

```
[{"id":"75320074d5b6ea81","type":"mqtt out","z":"f3e722a5c3be8f8c","name":"flowfuse/opcua/demo/ns2/i1/...","topic":"","qos":"","retain":"","respTopic":"","contentType":"","userProps":"","correl":"","expiry":"","broker":"54f84b78a482e509","x":1070,"y":360,"wires":[]},{"id":"a4289cfe1861b9cd","type":"inject","z":"f3e722a5c3be8f8c","name":"","props":[{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"flowfuse/test-data","x":990,"y":300,"wires":[["e16d7a950a9f992a"]]},{"id":"e16d7a950a9f992a","type":"function","z":"f3e722a5c3be8f8c","name":"captured data","func":"msg.payload = {\n    \"alarms\": {\n        \"alarm1\":false,\n        \"alarm1counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm2\":false,\n        \"alarm2counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm3\":false,\n        \"alarm3counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm4\":false,\n        \"alarm4counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm5\":false,\n        \"alarm5counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm6\":false,\n        \"alarm6counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm7\":false,\n        \"alarm7counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm8\":false,\n        \"alarm8counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm9\":false,\n        \"alarm9counter\":0n,\n        \"alarm10\":false,\n        \"alarm10counter\":0n\n        },\n    \"IntVariable\":31133n,\n    \"UIntVariable\":30188n,\n    \"FloatVariable\":99.76536083860492\n}\nreturn msg;","outputs":1,"timeout":0,"noerr":0,"initialize":"","finalize":"","libs":[],"x":1180,"y":300,"wires":[["75320074d5b6ea81"]]},{"id":"54f84b78a482e509","type":"mqtt-broker","name":"","broker":"broker.emqx.io","port":1883,"clientid":"","autoConnect":true,"usetls":false,"protocolVersion":"5","keepalive":60,"cleansession":true,"autoUnsubscribe":true,"birthTopic":"","birthQos":"0","birthRetain":"false","birthPayload":"","birthMsg":{},"closeTopic":"","closeQos":"0","closeRetain":"false","closePayload":"","closeMsg":{},"willTopic":"","willQos":"0","willRetain":"false","willPayload":"","willMsg":{},"userProps":"","sessionExpiry":""}]
```

### Request

In order to parse and send the data I had to recursively iterate all the keys in the object, test their type and convert. This is not fun. I hope we can find a low-code (no code) approach for the Node-RED experience.

### Personal thoughts

An approach I feel could work may include elements of the following...

We update JSON serialise internally in all places we do auto parsing (MQTT, HTTP, JSON node etc) to support conversion of Bigint to several forms.
1. Regular Number (lossy). Where the bigint is converted to Number type irrespective of precision loss.
2. Regular Number (strict). Where if the number is > safe min/max integer it throws
3. Custom object format specifying value and type

e.g. the nodes have a new typed input option named "Bigint Handling" offering 
1. No handling (default)
2. Convert to number (lossy)
3. Convert to number (strict)
4. Convert to Object with value and type.


I may even be tempted to say lossy conversion should be the default.

I dont think we can be opinionated here. Since auto parsing to number type would start "working" in some users flows where they expected to catch an error.  And, I can see places where I _know_ the number will never be > max safe integer but it is delivered as a bigint and thus lossy conversion is the right choice.  Then there are other places (like erp/mes) where I would accept a typed conversion.

title: Lack of Visual Differentiation Between Connected and Wire-Overlapping Nodes in the Editor
body:
### Current Behavior

In the Node-RED Editor, when a node is placed directly over a wire without being connected to it, there is no visual indication distinguishing this overlap from an actual connection. Both scenarios appear identical, leading to potential misinterpretation of the flow's structure at a glance.

### Expected Behavior

The Editor should provide a clear visual cue to differentiate between:â€‹

- Nodes that are genuinely connected to a wire.â€‹
- Nodes that are merely overlapping / placed on top of a wire without any connection.

### Proposed Solutions
- **Visual Indicators**: Implement a distinct visual style on the connection points (color?) of nodes that are actually connected wires rather than overlapping.â€‹ (This seems better than the reverse, since _connection_ is the active state.)
- **Connection Validation**: Introduce a validation feature that alerts users to nodes placed over wires without connections, preventing potential misconfigurations.â€‹ This is probably overkill though.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Open the Node-RED editor.â€‹
2. Create two nodes and connect them with a wire.â€‹
3. Drag a third node and position it over the existing wire without connecting it.â€‹
4. Observe that the third node appears as if it's part of the flow, despite not being connected.

### Example flow

[obvious]

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.0.8
- Node.js version: 20.12.2
- npm version: 10.9.0
- Platform/OS: macOS
- Browser: Chrome

title: FR: support pluggable auto-complete for MQTT nodes
body:
Within FlowFuse, we have a feature that monitors an MQTT broker and builds a list of in-use topics and allow the user to add schema/meta-data.

We want to find a way to make this information useful within the editor - in particular, being able to provide auto-complete suggestions for the topic field within the MQTT node.

The proposal here is to create a plugin interface for the MQTT nodes to create a 'topic auto-complete provider'.

 - A Node-RED Plugin would register itself with a type of `node-red-mqtt-topic-autocomplete`
 - The plugin would provide a function that can be called to get autocomplete suggests for a given broker config
 - This would need to be a runtime plugin as we cannot expose API credentials to the frontend
 - We will need a mechanism for the frontend to know there are autocomplete plugins registered so the UI code can enable auto-complete on the topic field.

If there are multiple plugins registered, the response will need to be combined.

title: FR: Declarative creation of typedinputs
FR: Add credential type to Change/Inject nodes
body:
Ref: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/feature-request-please-add-credential-input-to-inject-and-change-node/95645

Proposal to add the built-in credential type to the appropriate TypedInputs in the Change/Inject nodes. Off the top of my head, I can't think of a technical limitation that would prevent that.

The workaround today is to define an env var at the Flow level as a credential type property, and then reference that in the Change/Inject node. Is that a good enough workaround not to change anything?  

Raising here so we don't lose sight of it.

title: FR: Support display of symbols in the debug sidebar
body:
Request: Show symbols in the debug pane similar to popular IDEs watch/debug view
Why: Currently, the debug sidebar does not show symbols in the object. Symbols can be very useful. For example, to avoid overwriting existing properties in a `msg`.   

See #5046 for details, screenshot and reasoning.

title: Add support for symbols
body:
### Current Behavior

When using a symbol as a property in the function node it reports an "error":

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1dd54d25-ff82-4b7e-be9c-02d5025cbed4)

`Type 'symbol' cannot be used as an index type.(2538)`


Also, symbols belonging to a msg are not shown in the debug output

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c0576652-fac2-4c1e-ae77-f96037c60944)

For reference, I mentioned this first here: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/logio-logging-on-steroids/94690/11?u=steve-mcl

The function/monaco should not complain symbols.  This is a typescript version thing. The easiest way around this is to disable error `2538` in the monaco diagnostics settings by default

The Debug output should show symbols in the msg.  For example, this is how devtools shows symbols:

title: Some nodes does not trigger `onComplete` hook
body:
### Current Behavior

Some nodes like `http in` or `tcp in` does not trigger `onComplete` [hook](https://nodered.org/docs/api/hooks/messaging/#oncomplete).

### Expected Behavior

All nodes should emit an `onComplete` event when they are completed.

### Steps To Reproduce

Adding a hook like this (or use my [OpenTelemetry node](https://github.com/nioc/node-red-contrib-opentelemetry)):

``` js
  RED.hooks.add('onComplete.test', (event) => {
    let msg = `_msgId: ${event.msg._msgid}:`
    if (event.source && event.source.node) {
      msg += ` src: ${event.source.node.type} ${event.source.node.id}`
    }
    if (event.destination && event.destination.node) {
      msg += ` >> dest: ${event.destination.node.type} ${event.destination.node.id}`
    }
    if (event.node && event.node.node) {
      msg += ` ## node: ${event.node.node.type} ${event.node.node.id}`
    }
    console.log(`onComplete: ${msg}`)
  })

title: Move some `importNodes` logic to external functions
body:
- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Part of #4757.

This first part of the `importNodes` refactoring moves some logic into functions:

- `identifyUnknownTypes`
- `copyConfigNode`
- `copyNode`

`identifyUnknownTypes` adds a loop in this PR but another one will disappear in the future.

I haven't fixed any issues (added todo flag) except in one place: L2469 if the id is updated at this line, the condition at line L2492 will no longer be true. Import copy force `generateIds` to true that's why never detected before. But I wonder if it is not the subflow id that should be used instead of node id.

title: HTTP Request failed after I upgraded docker version Node-Red from 3.1 to 4.x
body:
### Current Behavior

I have a simple HTTP POST workflow created in my node-red instance (docker). It's been working fine for more than a year already. Because the request is so basic, I do not expect to see it failing when upgrading Node-Red.

However, recently I upgraded from Node-Red 3.1 to 4.0 (docker), this HTTP POST flow no longer works now. It has very generic error message "Request Error" followed by the HTTP request url.

When running on node-red 3.1 (docker), it runs ok (been like that for a year)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ed75ec65-580a-41e0-a0ab-7b16a250babb)

after upgrading to node-red 4.0 (docker), it stops working
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5abe9430-6bc5-4fb1-8c43-97a9c62b36f3)


### Expected Behavior

Expect to see a HTTP response 200 with payload.

I have a Postman version of this request created long time ago, and this request works just fine, which proves that this is a bug introduced in Node-Red 4.0.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1bfccdaa-8472-492a-8126-d6d1aac87dbd)



### Steps To Reproduce

Pull the docker image from [nodered/node-red:3.1]
Run the simple flow, it shall work fine.

Pull the docker image from [nodered/node-red:4.0] (I tried the latest which is 4.0.5, same issue)
Run the simple flow, it fails.


### Example flow

```json
[
    {
        "id": "4f366d1142482ee8",
        "type": "tab",
        "label": "Debug Flow",
        "disabled": false,
        "info": "",
        "env": []
    },
    {
        "id": "4d915eba3b469fcf",
        "type": "inject",
        "z": "4f366d1142482ee8",
        "name": "inject",
        "props": [
            {
                "p": "payload"
            }
        ],
        "repeat": "",
        "crontab": "",
        "once": true,
        "onceDelay": 0.1,
        "topic": "",
        "payload": "",
        "payloadType": "date",
        "x": 810,
        "y": 140,
        "wires": [
            [
                "b163c76c57b518b9"
            ]
        ]

title: Propagate errors when testing
body:
Testing with Mocha requires errors raised within flows to propagate to the test runner, not getting swallowed by Node-Red.

This commit tests whether Mocha's global functions exist and, if they do, propagates exceptions that are raised there.

- [X] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

When running under Mocha, Node-Red must propagate exceptions to the test runner so that suitable error messages can be emitted instead of a timeout.

This closes issue #4956.

Suggestions how to test for this feature, should such a test be deemed necessary, are welcome. I have to admit that I am not well-versed enough in Javascript, Mocha and/or Node-Red lore to write a test for this specific issue that's not (a) visual, or (b) would be a copy of the test that the "detect-mocha" module already does.

## Checklist
<!-- Put an `x` in the boxes that apply -->

- [ ] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [X] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Errors get discarded / logged to Nirvana when testing node-red flows
body:
### Current Behavior

Errors raised from within NR flows do not propagate. This is a bad idea when running a test suite.

The effect is that e.g. in the `node-red-nodes` tree, `npr mocha FILE` either succeeds or times out, but does *not* show an actionable error message if/when it fails.

This has two ugly consequences, (a) it makes writing comprehensive tests for node-red extensions excessively difficult because it's difficult to discover what went wrong, (b) when an error occurs on CI infrastructure but is not immediately reproducible locally it's all but impossible to figure out the cause of the problem.

### Expected Behavior

The failing test should state what's wrong. A timeout with (apparently) no way to recover the error message is broken.

Thus I'd expect the `catch` stanzas in `node-red/runtime/lib/nodes/Node.js:221`and `node-red/runtime/lib/flows/Flow.js:807` to re-throw the exception when running under Mocha.

### Steps To Reproduce

Check out `node-red-nodes`, `npm install`.
Edit `test/parsers/base64/70-base64_spec.js` , change the ABC in line 38 to AbC or so, then run `npr mocha test/parsers/base64/70-base64_spec.js`.

Observe a timeout.

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.0.1
- Node.js version: 20.17.0
- npm version: 9.2.0
- Platform/OS: Debian testing
- Browser: n/a

title: Move location of new creds files to be next to flows (if they don't exist already in userdir)
body:
<!--
## Before you hit that Submit button....

Please read our [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
before submitting a pull-request.

## Types of changes

What types of changes does your code introduce?
Put an `x` in the boxes that apply
-->

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

<!--
If you want to raise a pull-request with a new feature, or a refactoring
of existing code, it **may well get rejected** if it hasn't been discussed on
the [forum](https://discourse.nodered.org) or
[slack team](https://nodered.org/slack) first.

-->

## Proposed changes

If you specify the location of the flows file to be somewhere else then currently the flows_cred.json file remains located in the userdir. This PR checks to see if the file already exists in the userdir (so as not to break existing uses) - but if not - then it creates the cred file in the same directory as the flows so that copying them manually is simplified.
It also means that when using docker and setting the flows to be mounted outside the container for persistence then the creds are also persisted alongside them.
Hopefully this doesn't break existing users - but as it is a change of behaviour it may need a serious version bump.

After upgrading all of my Home Assistant nodes, it had about 15 that had issues which needed resolved. My final issue was with a call for a script that it didn't like. title: FR: Enable browse by category in the Palette Manager
body:
We're introducing categories to the public node catalogue. This will be reflected in the catalog json the editor loads as a `categories` property which is an array of string category names. This isn't quite live yet - will update this issue when its done.

We want to update the Manage Palette to allow the user to browse/filter the catalog by these categories. It's also an chance to reexamine the overall UX of the palette manager when browsing. Want to look at making it easier to find useful nodes.
