title: let multiplayer name be set in browser storage rather than fully anonymous
body:
<!--
## Before you hit that Submit button....

Please read our [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
before submitting a pull-request.

## Types of changes

What types of changes does your code introduce?
Put an `x` in the boxes that apply
-->

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

<!--
If you want to raise a pull-request with a new feature, or a refactoring
of existing code, it **may well get rejected** if it hasn't been discussed on
the [forum](https://discourse.nodered.org) or
[slack team](https://nodered.org/slack) first.

-->

## Proposed changes

When using multiplayer option when not logged in you get assigned a random Anon-XYZ id - which then changes every time you refresh the browser connection. It would be nice to be able to set this to a fixed / useful value in someway so that you can make use of this multiplayer capability in situations where you may not have or need authenticated users. 

This PR lets the name be set by using a value stored in the browser localstorage area.
So far this PR does not provide a UI to set this value but it can easily be tested by using the developer javascript console and using the command ` localStorage.setItem("multiplayer-name", "Fred") ` etc

Even without a UI I think the plumbing for this is useful to explore the concept.

title: Inject nodes and Debug nodes are not executable, and nodes that query HA entity states are not displaying state under nodes.
body:
# Please see to the HA Add-on Issue: https://github.com/hassio-addons/addon-node-red/issues/1960

_Update from @knolleary:_ This is not a core Node-RED issue. We're keeping this issue open for HA users who come to us looking for help.


### Current Behavior

Inject and debug nodes appear to be disabled when you open the Node-Red web UI through Home Assistant (Setttings/Add-ons/Node-Red, then click "Open web UI"). Additionally, nodes that acquire state, such as the event.state, poll-state, etc no longer show the state below the node(s) (See FIG-1) 

FIG-1
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ad6e7446-65d3-4602-a9e6-73cf8c2049a6)


However, if you open node-red web ui directly, through port 1800, inject, debug and nodes that interact with Home Assistant nodes are working as expected (See FIG-2)

FIG-2
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/543f19ef-371c-48c7-9764-2b1b06230eb6)




### Expected Behavior

Inject and debug nodes should work through the embeded HA web ui. The nodes that interact with Home Assistant entities should show the state. 

### Steps To Reproduce

Open, HA, Go to Node-Red add-on, open Node-Red Web UI. 

Issue 1: Once loaded, all inject nodes, debug nodes and nodes are disabled. Unable to execute these nodes.

Issue: 2: Nodes that use home assistant entities are not displaying state of the entity below the node. Flows still appear to be working. This appears to be a visual problem.  

### Example flow

All Flows are experiencing this issue. 


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4.0.3
- Node.js version: where do I get this?
- npm version: where do I get this?
- Platform/OS: Home Assistant 2024.10.0
- Browser: Chrome Version 128.0.6613.138 (Official Build) (64-bit)

title: Bump peter-evans/create-pull-request from 6 to 7 in the github-actions group

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
Bumps the github-actions group with 1 update: [peter-evans/create-pull-request](https://github.com/peter-evans/create-pull-request). Updates `peter-evans/create-pull-request` from 6 to 7
Release notes

Sourced from peter-evans/create-pull-request's releases.

Create Pull Request v7.0.0

:sparkles: Now supports commit signing with bot-generated tokens! See "What's new" below. :writing_hand::robot:

Behaviour changes

  • Action input git-token has been renamed branch-token, to be more clear about its purpose. The branch-token is the token that the action will use to create and update the branch.
  • The action now handles requests that have been rate-limited by GitHub. Requests hitting a primary rate limit will retry twice, for a total of three attempts. Requests hitting a secondary rate limit will not be retried.
  • The pull-request-operation output now returns none when no operation was executed.
  • Removed deprecated output environment variable PULL_REQUEST_NUMBER. Please use the pull-request-number action output instead.

What's new

  • The action can now sign commits as github-actions[bot] when using GITHUB_TOKEN, or your own bot when using GitHub App tokens. See commit signing for details.
  • Action input draft now accepts a new value always-true. This will set the pull request to draft status when the pull request is updated, as well as on creation.
  • A new action input maintainer-can-modify indicates whether maintainers can modify the pull request. The default is true, which retains the existing behaviour of the action.
  • A new output pull-request-commits-verified returns true or false, indicating whether GitHub considers the signature of the branch's commits to be verified.

title: Feat: add `$dayjs` support to the Expressions Engine.
body:
## Types of changes



- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)



## Proposed changes

As discussed on the forum : https://discourse.nodered.org/t/jsonata-moment-dayjs

This PR introduces `$dayjs` to the expressions engine.

![Screenshot 2024-09-30 at 11 08 06](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/14963a06-90ba-409c-ba52-fab838d79504)

![Screenshot 2024-09-30 at 11 08 51](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/90f5e867-d797-4ea5-87bc-bd4353f63df6)

My view here, is to move over to the modern/smaller equivalent of `$moment`
According to my research, many have transitioned from, or have removed support for `moment`, and switched to `dayjs`

I haven't done anything to `$moment`, as I think this PR should represent a move away from it.
Happy to discuss any hurdles that may not be seen by myself.


## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: [Feature Request] Environment variables: Support "config node" type on groups and tabs
body:
As discussed on the forum: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/environment-variables-support-config-node-type-on-groups-and-tabs/91219

Starting with Node-RED 4, *config nodes* can be configured as subflow parameters in its environment list.

This feature could be extended to the environment variable lists of **editor groups** and **tabs**, and if possible even the global  environment located in the settings dialog.

#### Advantages

* set a config node for a group of nodes in one place
* change the config node without having to open/edit every single node
* when moving nodes to another group/tab,, it can automatically use the config node from the local environment over there, without changing the node's config

#### Example use case

In combination with Dashboard nodes, it can ease the configuration effort of single widgets a lot. You could simply group them in the editor and set the ui-group node in a single place.

As a generic feature, I'm certain this can be useful for other nodes with config nodes as well (mqtt broker, database config, ...).

title: Clarify the role of node validation and `TypedInput`
body:
## Description **Reminder**: when the edit box is built, for each property defined in `node.defaults` a change handler is attached (`attachPropertyChangeHandler`) to the corresponding input. This handler triggers the validation of all properties defined in `node.defaults`. The validator comes from `node.defaults`. Consider the following example of a TypedInput: ```html
``` Built with the `msg` type which has an internal validator. ```js $("#node-input-foo").typedInput({ typeField: "#node-input-fooType", types: "msg", }); ``` - Without validator defined in the node ```js { defaults: { foo: { value: "" }, } } ``` If the user completes a field, as mentioned in my reminder, my foo input will be validated with the node validator. Since it doesn't exist it will get the value from the TypedInput validator. If the user now completes the foo field, the TypedInput validator is triggered AND also the node validator. Which is equivalent to validating twice with the TypedInput validator. Note: node validation will only work if the DOM element exists. e.g. if closing the edit box marks an error, refreshing the page will no longer mark the node as an error. - With validator defined in the node ```js { defaults: { foo: { value: "", validate: RED.validators.typedInput("fooType") }, } } ``` If I now have a validator in the node, whether the user completes my foo field or another will trigger two validations (TypedInput and the node) with the consequence that the node is stronger. If the TypedInput validation returns an error but the node validation does not, the field will not be in error. **Conclusion**: The goal of this issue is to highlight that a double validation exists for TypedInput inputs and that we should agree on the role of each because currently for these inputs the TypedInput validator is not highlighted (because overwritten). My suggestion would be that `attachPropertyChangeHandler` does not attach to TypedInput inputs so that two validators can be defined. The TypedInput validator when the user completes this field and the node validator for other cases (save node...). This allows each validator to do its job. Another interest is that the node passed in context to the node validator will contain the up-to-date values - this is useful if the validation depends on another property. **Clarification**: this double validation problem has existed for a long time but its consequences have only existed recently: - node validator uses TypedInput result (#4455) - TypedInput mark the field in error (#4747) - this clearly implies that before TypedInput did not mark that fields ## Related Links [Related conversation on the Forum](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/feedback-wanted-typedinput-and-node-validation/90033).

title: feature: add option to disable Inject node button
body:
I've just created a flow that needs to run on a schedule every day. It must *not* be run manually as that could lead to duplicate processing/data.

Rather than install a 3rd party cron node, I've used the core Inject node which is certainly up to the job. I have set the name of the node to 'DO NOT RUN MANUALLY' to remind me (and others in the team) not click the inject button.

It would be useful to have an option to disable the Inject node's button for this use case.

title: CSV Node with single-lined csv does not correctly handle 'parts' property in message object
body:
### Current Behavior

There seems to be an issue with the CSV node when handling messages that include the msg.parts property. The msg.parts originates from a previous split node to parse multiple CSV files. I have identified four different test scenarios that demonstrate the issue, which I've detailed below.

### Expected Behavior

The CSV node should process the single-lined csv and output the parsed data.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Test Scenario 1: Single Line CSV with msg.parts
- Inject a message with a single line CSV payload and a msg.parts property originates from splitting multiple files.
- Expected Result: The CSV node should process the line and output the parsed data.
- Actual Result: No message is output from the CSV node.

2. Test Scenario 2: Single Line CSV with Deleted msg.parts
- Inject the same message as Scenario 1, but delete the msg.parts property before it reaches the CSV node.
- Expected Result: The CSV node processes the line and outputs the parsed data correctly.
- Actual Result: The CSV node outputs the parsed data as expected.

3. Test Scenario 3: Adjusted msg.parts with Count = 1
- Inject a message with a single line CSV payload and a msg.parts property where count=1 and index=0.
- Expected Result: The CSV node should process the line and output the parsed data.
- Actual Result: The CSV node outputs an empty array instead of the expected parsed data.

4. Test Scenario 4: Multi-line CSV
- Inject a message with a multi-line CSV payload and a msg.parts property originates from splitting multiple files.
- Expected Result: The CSV node should process the lines and output the parsed data for each line.
- Actual Result: The CSV node functions as expected and outputs the parsed data for each line.

In all four test scenarios, the CSV node is configured to output one message for all rows ("multi": "mult").

title: Build CSS not compatible with every browser
body:
### Current Behavior

Current CSS build process: SCSS -> CSS

Problem some browsers like Safari still need some vendor specific prefix for a minor set of css like `user-select`.
See https://caniuse.com/mdn-css_properties_user-select , https://github.com/node-red/node-red/pull/4769#discussion_r1643464217 and #4720 .


### Expected Behavior

Add vendor specific css **or** better use tool which adds vendor specific prefix if necessary.

Common tool-chain: https://postcss.org/ + https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer

For grunt a maintained fork is: https://github.com/C-Lodder/grunt-postcss

Possible CSS build process: SCSS -> postcss + autoprefixer -> CSS

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4-dev
- Browser: Safari

title: Replace dependency `is-utf8`
body:
### Current Behavior

The dependency `is-utf8` has it latest release `0.2.1` in [2015](https://www.npmjs.com/package/is-utf8/v/0.2.1) and seems to have some issues: https://github.com/wayfind/is-utf8/issues/6

### Expected Behavior

Use a maintained dependency or native implementation.

This project already uses websocket library `ws` which offers its own utf8 library [utf-8-validate](https://github.com/websockets/utf-8-validate).

By increasing required node version to new patch level 18.5 -> 18.14 it is possible to use native implementation https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v18.x/api/buffer.html#bufferisutf8input .


The native implementation would be preferable, but tests fail.


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4-dev
- Node.js version: 20

_No response_

title: Refactoring the `RED.nodes.import()` function
body:
- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Refactoring the `importNodes` function.

Resolves also:

- Bad number of `node.users` for Config Node:
  - Deleting a Node inside a Subflow does not update the number of users.
  - Replacing a Config Node overwrites the user list to empty.

- A Node that has an invalid number of inputs/outputs (dynamic number) is not correctly handled.

- When copying a Subflow (tab), the name is not updated (addition of the copy count)

- When importing a Subflow:
  - If the definition is missing, the Node will be marked as unknown - which allows to double click and have dialog box and be able to export this Node.
  - When adding the definition, existing instances into the workspace are updated.
  - A Node missing into the Subflow import is now handled (to avoid create link)

- Ensure `activeWorkspace` can no longer be equal to 0.

Other functions modified:

- `updateConfigNodeUsers` - for either add or remove and either trigger the event
- `RED.view.importNodes()` - overwrite importMap to undefined

## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [ ] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.

title: Undesirable behaviour when _bad_ JSON entered into TypedInput
body:
### Current Behavior

When I paste JSON with duplicate key, then expand the editor, my JSON is unexpectantly changed (sanitised)

### demo
![chrome_HKBDD3RXWg](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/44235289/eff8869f-a5f6-4d86-ae74-920d4bf50d4f)


#### JSON I used
```
{     "info": "hello",     "abc": "123",     "fff": "www",     "info": "xxxxx" }
```


### Expected Behavior

1. JSON entered in text field should be faithfully presented in the editor warts n all
    2.  This allows me to "see my error" and "fix it up" the way I want to (not take the first key)
2.  TypedInput validator should highlight this as an issue

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Add an inject --> debug
2. set payload to `{     "info": "hello",     "abc": "123",     "fff": "www",     "info": "xxxxx" }`
3. deploy and inject
4. debug outputs `{ "info": "xxxxx",     "abc": "123",     "fff": "www" }`

title: editor-client: mixed dependencies
body:
### Current Behavior

As mentioned in https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/4738#issuecomment-2139489439 editor-client uses mixed dependencies: local copies and npm.


### Expected Behavior

It would be beneficial to have most dependencies managed by npm and just custom build dependencies as local copy.
Advantage: with `npm outdated` it is easier to keep overview over outdated dependencies.
Disadvantage: currently build does not warn if required files due path or naming change are not available fixed by #4739

### Steps To Reproduce

npm dependency:
- `jquery-i18next`

local copy which can be moved to npm:
- `jquery`
- `jquery-ui`
- `jquery-ui-touch-punch`
- `d3`

notes:
- `jquery-ui-touch-punch` - seems very old and abandoned(?), updated version available
- `d3` bump to lates v3?

@knolleary give me a ping if I should create a pr.

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 4-dev
- Node.js version: 20

body:

title: Proposal: new format for settings file
body:
Our current settings file is structured as a big Object:

```
module.exports = {
   flowFile: 'flows.json',
   ...
}
```

This is fine if you're used to working with objects - and that you remember to add a comma between any entries you add. This trips some users up and they end up with an invalid settings file. It's also a pain to have to add a comment about ensuring you add a comma whenever the docs talk about adding values.

I happened to be in the gitlab admin docs and noticed how they document their settings file:

```
gitlab_rails['some_setting'] = true
gitlab_rails['some_other_setting'] = {
    'label' => 'hi',
    'host' =>  'example.com
}
```
Putting aside its ruby, not JavaScript - the key point is the settings are individual statements on a top level object.
This removes the issues around getting the formatting right when adding new settings -  whether a comma is needed or not.


I propose changing our default settings file to be structured like this:

```
const settings = module.exports = {}

settings['flowFile'] = 'flows.json'

settings['adminAuth'] = {
   type: "credentials",
   ...
}

```

I'm in two minds whether to use dot notation (`settings.flowFile`) or bracket notation (`settings['flowFile']`) - which is more accessible to non-JS users?

Raising this as an issue rather than jumping straight to PR to save the effort reformatting what we've got if this is a terrible idea.

title: "Otherwise" evaluated to early in switch node
body:
### Current Behavior

Due to flow layout reasons I changed the order of the cases in the switch node to

1. otherwise
2. my condition

I recognized that the message is forwarded to both outputs which causes unexpected behavior.

### Expected Behavior

The order of the cases should be honored. Nevertheless I expect the "otherwise" to be evaluated at last wherever it is located in the conditions of the switch node.

### Steps To Reproduce

- Create a inject node that outputs 10.
- Add a switch node with two cases
- First case "otherwise"
- Second case "==10"
- Connect debug nodes to the outputs

You will see that the message "10" is printed for both outputs.

title: Support Property in out on core nodes
body:
## Types of changes

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

In alignment with proposals in #4651:

* Adds "Property Out" field where sensible
* Updates "Property In" field to clarify input/output

### Nodes Updated:

In the format proposed by #4651, the `name` field was moved to the top, the input property is next and the new (or existing) output property was placed at the end (or at the end of main properties / above the `<hr>` and advanced properties in some nodes)





### TODO:
- [x] Post before and after screenshots in the issue for evaluation and agreement
- [x] Write tests for affected nodes.  
   - Where applicable, tests should set `property` and verify the input data should be taken from the correct `msg` property
   - Where applicable, tests should set `propertyOut` and verify the results go to the correct `msg` property
- [ ] Update built in help for affected nodes
- [x] Switch PR out of draft

## Checklist
- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [x] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: FR: core nodes to permit input and output to properties other than the hard coded payload
body:
Discussed and triaged with @dceejay but again, i am failing to find the supporting information.  Dave listed out all the nodes where this made sense.  I will update this once I locate the preparations/supporting discussion.

The PR proposes that, where it makes sense, we permit the input and output property to be user configurable.

It was determined this would be strictly a `msg.xyz` only option as this simplifies implementation and promotes the use of `msg` properties (over context or other potentially mutating values)


The aim is to reduce friction when flows are made in a serial fashion whereby users are not aware they can move or copy the `payload` to an alternate `msg` property (using change nodes). The first instinct many users seem to apply is to store the payload in context and then pick this up at the end of the flow. This leads to subtle timing bugs when messages flow in quick succession and async operations are involved.

title: FR: Align "Name" field across core nodes
body:
This was discussed and agreed with @dceejay (though I am failing to find the issue/thread/discussion)

As it stands, core nodes have random placement of the Name field.  

This FR is to propose that the Name field be placed 1st on all core nodes to create a familiar layout.

### Example (non exhaustive)

#### Nodes with Name as 1st field:
* Inject
* Change
* Function
* Template
* Link-in/out/call

#### Nodes with Name as last field:
* Debug/Catch/complete/status
* Exec
* Filter
* MQTT/TCP
* Split/Join/sort/Batch

#### Nodes with Name in the middle
* CSV
* XML

title: Follow up CSV node msg.columns bug #2853
body:
### Current Behavior

see issue #2853:
The issue only occurs if a CSV node is used in a sequence and the columns property of a CSV node is initially empty:
In this case the columns property of a CSV node is set correctly during processing the first part of a sequence.
But the columns property is not updated during the second and other following parts. So, all written data files contain wrong header followed by rows with empty values only.

This behaviour is exactly the same like in closed issue #2853 - obviously the issue was not fixed successfully.

### Expected Behavior

For every part in a sequence, the CSV node should not only set the payload to msg.payload but also set the columns property to the current value of msg.columns.

I've seen that if I have a node that has a large output size (e.g. a large array), when I split the output across multiple nodes there is a major performance hit, even if the other nodes aren't using the data

paste your flow here

title: tls-config node local file issue
body:
### Current Behavior

When TLS is enabled and the "Use key and cert from local files" is checked and deployed the node will error with "RequestError: unable to verify the first certificate"
![image](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/147643753/24aa4724-602a-40c4-b033-0b7ffe1059e1)
![Capture](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/147643753/5335fa74-7cc0-4469-a804-4bf962410dcb)
This error will continue until node-red is restarted and then it will function fine.  The other work around is check the box "Verify server certificate" deploy then uncheck the box "Verify server certificate" and deploy.  
![image](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/147643753/ca3cf86d-103a-41fd-ba09-7753d81d5edd)

Using a node-red in a Docker container a restart does not fix it.  The only way to get it to work is check the box "Verify server certificate" deploy then uncheck the box "Verify server certificate" and deploy.  This is an issue because any restart will cause it not to work.

Curl works fine.


### Expected Behavior

_No response_

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Example flow

```
paste your flow here
[
    {
        "id": "9f273657491a8522",
        "type": "http request",
        "z": "c1fc7d91625d25a8",
        "name": "",
        "method": "POST",
        "ret": "txt",
        "paytoqs": "ignore",
        "url": "https://endpoint",

title: Csv doesn't handle csv file with CR+LF (windows) not always correct
body:
### Current Behavior

On a windows machine the core Csv node will handle the CR+LF not correct.
When the checkbox **Include empty string** is set there will be 2 messages per row, instead of one.

See for details: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/strange-behaviour-csv-node/85747


### Expected Behavior

The expected behavior should be only 1 message per csv row.
Removing the LF from the row will solve the problem, tested and confirmed.

### Steps To Reproduce

[booking.csv](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/files/14365441/booking.csv)


### Example flow

```
[{"id":"61b9e0b5ddd16b80","type":"csv","z":"9e38d6c8b155bad2","name":"","sep":",","hdrin":true,"hdrout":"none","multi":"one","ret":"\\r\\n","temp":"","skip":"0","strings":false,"include_empty_strings":true,"include_null_values":true,"x":530,"y":460,"wires":[["7856411b210cf3f9"]]},{"id":"cbbab2d7a33172b0","type":"file in","z":"9e38d6c8b155bad2","name":"","filename":"payload","filenameType":"msg","format":"utf8","chunk":false,"sendError":false,"encoding":"utf8","allProps":false,"x":540,"y":380,"wires":[["61b9e0b5ddd16b80","cc6f864112b94d3d"]]},{"id":"85abdc5b6dde425f","type":"inject","z":"9e38d6c8b155bad2","name":"","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"","payload":"C:\\\\temp\\\\booking.csv","payloadType":"str","x":560,"y":300,"wires":[["cbbab2d7a33172b0"]]},{"id":"7856411b210cf3f9","type":"debug","z":"9e38d6c8b155bad2","name":"debug 10","active":true,"tosidebar":true,"console":false,"tostatus":false,"complete":"true","targetType":"full","statusVal":"","statusType":"auto","x":760,"y":460,"wires":[]},{"id":"cc6f864112b94d3d","type":"debug","z":"9e38d6c8b155bad2","name":"debug 11","active":false,"tosidebar":true,"console":false,"tostatus":false,"complete":"true","targetType":"full","statusVal":"","statusType":"auto","x":760,"y":380,"wires":[]}]

title: Failed to start server : Invalid JSON in context file
body:
After a power failure, the file **global.json** was altered. I have attached the altered file as an example.
The problem would be that the node-red server stopped starting.

```
Welcome to Node-RED
===================
14 Feb 14:00:47 - [info] Node-RED version: v3.1.5
14 Feb 14:00:47 - [info] Node.js  version: v16.20.2
14 Feb 14:00:47 - [info] Windows_NT 10.0.19045 x64 LE
14 Feb 14:00:48 - [info] Loading palette nodes
14 Feb 14:00:49 - [info] Settings file  : C:\Users\DEV\.node-red\settings.js
14 Feb 14:00:49 - [info] Context store  : 'ram' [module=memory]
14 Feb 14:00:49 - [info] Context store  : 'hdd' [module=localfilesystem]
14 Feb 14:00:49 - [error] Failed to start server:
14 Feb 14:00:49 - [error] Error: Error loading context store: Error: Invalid JSON in context file '\Users\DEV\.node-red\context\global\global.json'
    at C:\Users\DEV\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\node-red\node_modules\@node-red\runtime\lib\nodes\context\index.js:180:15
```

Maybe it would be better that in the case that the **global.json** file is altered, the server should notify the error, but still start.
It's better to start again, than to stay stopped.


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.1.5
- Node.js version: 16.20.2
- npm version: 10.4.0
- Platform/OS: Windows 10 x64
- Browser: -

title: node-red web SVG UI performance degradation due to forced reflow with large number of nodes
body:
### Current Behavior

When there is a large number of nodes in the Node-RED Web UI, forced reflow occurs, leading to performance degradation.
Descend to around ten frames per second

### Expected Behavior

The Node-RED Web UI should maintain optimal performance even with a large number of nodes.

### Steps To Reproduce

Create a Node-RED flow with a large number of nodes.
Drag a line from the right end of one node.
Observe the performance degradation in the Web UI.

https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/43309591/9a1531ab-bf75-4fb1-913f-478c50217961

title: [Feature Request] : Make reference to Debug Node max char default
body:
**WARNING** : The most complicated FR below!

As per a conversation with Steve:
https://discourse.nodered.org/t/feature-request-move-debug-max-chars-into-node-settings/84864

I originally suggested to move the max char setting, to the Node itself.
whilst this has benefits, it has the potential for users to cause more performance issues for themself.

So,
it was suggested to instead make a reference to the Max char defaults in the node (say a form tip), to remove the confusion with users wondering why their messages seem to be "not complete" and suggesting there is a problem with the runtime

title: "Error: Cannot find module" when specifying `function` node module version
body: ### Current Behavior A `function` node species a specific version of a module: When it is deployed, it correctly installs the specified version of the package; however, it fails to import it: ``` 23 Jan 20:24:47 - [info] Stopping flows 23 Jan 20:24:47 - [info] Stopped flows 23 Jan 20:24:47 - [info] Updated flows 23 Jan 20:24:47 - [info] Installing module: pkginfo, version: 0.3.1 23 Jan 20:24:49 - [info] Installed module: pkginfo@0.3.1 23 Jan 20:24:49 - [info] Starting flows 23 Jan 20:24:49 - [error] [function:e4571de5204a6558] Error: Cannot find module 'pkginfo@0.3.1' Require stack: - /data/node_modules/pkginfo@0.3.1 23 Jan 20:24:49 - [info] Started flows ``` This was reported in the forums last year; however, I couldn't find an issue on GitHub about it. https://discourse.nodered.org/t/referring-to-a-specific-module-version-in-the-function-node/76633 ### Expected Behavior When a `function` node specifies a specific version of a module to install, that module should also be imported successfully. ### Steps To Reproduce Attempt to deploy and execute the sample flow. ### Example flow ``` [ { "id": "95af9ddfec641040", "type": "tab", "label": "Flow 1", "disabled": false, "info": "", "env": [] }, { "id": "e4571de5204a6558", "type": "function", "z": "95af9ddfec641040", "name": "function 7", "func": "\nreturn {version: pkginfo.version};", "outputs": 1, "timeout": 0, "noerr": 0, "initialize": "", "finalize": "", "libs": [ { "var": "pkginfo", "module": "pkginfo@0.3.1" } ], "x": 1080, "y": 240, "wires": [ [ "4ebef47db4a17322" ] ] }, { "id": "485563aa4f728dd0", "type": "inject", "z": "95af9ddfec641040", "name": "", "props": [ { "p": "payload" }, { "p": "topic", "vt": "str" } ], "repeat": "", "crontab": "", "once": false, "onceDelay": 0.1, "topic": "", "payload": "", "payloadType": "date", "x": 900, "y": 220, "wires": [ [ "e4571de5204a6558" ] ] }, { "id": "4ebef47db4a17322", "type": "debug", "z": "95af9ddfec641040", "name": "debug 18", "active": true, "tosidebar": true, "console": false, "tostatus": false, "complete": "true", "targetType": "full", "statusVal": "", "statusType": "auto", "x": 1300, "y": 240, "wires": [] } ] ``` ### Environment - Node-RED version: 3.1.3 - Node.js version: 16.20.2 - npm version: 8.19.4 - Platform/OS: **Docker image:** `nodered/node-red:3.1.3` **Docker host:** `Linux 6e93128c6163 5.15.133.1-microsoft-standard-WSL2 #1 SMP Thu Oct 5 21:02:42 UTC 2023 x86_64 Linux` - Browser: Microsoft Edge 120.0.2210.144 (Official build) (64-bit)

title: Fix 22 typos found by codespell
body:
Got to this project while looking at https://community.home-assistant.io/t/smart-oil-guage/284282/17 ... thought to contribute https://github.com/codespell-project/codespell action/config as I usually do but it would need more work, so decided to quickly at least provide fixes to some common typos it found:

Here are typos with their counts and introduced fix:

      1 autmatically ==> automatically
      1 commited ==> committed
      1 currenlty ==> currently
      1 dependecies ==> dependencies
      1 referrenced ==> referenced
      1 signleton ==> singleton
      1 somwhere ==> somewhere
      1 specied ==> specified
      1 specifiy ==> specify
      1 statment ==> statement
      1 successfuly ==> successfully
      1 unavaiable ==> unavailable
      2 ellapsed ==> elapsed
      3 arrray ==> array
      3 compatability ==> compatibility
      3 defintion ==> definition
      4 compability ==> compatibility
      4 mesage ==> message
      4 notifiction ==> notification
      5 re-use ==> reuse
      6 doesnt ==> does not
      6 non-existant ==> non-existent

Let's see if some changes (e.g. adding space to path ;)) break the tests 

## Checklist
<!-- Put an `x` in the boxes that apply -->

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [ ] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [ ] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality


feel welcome to close/drop if don't see the need etc... or feel welcome to pickup and finish up...

title: Delay node behavior for all messages and for each msg.topic inconsistent
body:
### Current Behavior

The built in Delay node's Rate Limit behavior for all messages and for each msg.topic is inconsistent. It immediately passes the initial message when set to all messages as expected, but delays the initial message when set to for each msg.topic

### Expected Behavior

The initial message should always pass immediately and only subsequent messages that fall within the delay period should be held up or dropped (depending on the behavior selected)

### Steps To Reproduce

In the web interface, create a delay note in the flow. Set Action to Rate Limit and All messages. Observe correct behavior where the initial message passes immediately. Edit the delay node to change All messages to For each msg.topic under Action. Observe the message is not passed immediately and instead waits until the delay timer is complete.

title: Old instances may keep running after re-deploying
body:
### Current Behavior

When changing connection settings (such as the address of the mqtt-broker) and deploying, if you were to change the address and re-deploy, there will still be network requests to that old address that should not be used anymore

### Expected Behavior

The network requests to that old address should stop

### Steps To Reproduce

For viewing the network packets i've used a Mikrotik router with Port Mirror enabled and Wireshark on the PC

1. Go to the mqtt-broker node
2. Set any address A and 
3. Click Update
4. Click Deploy
5. Requests will begin on address A
6. Change the address in the mqtt-broker node to address B
7. Click Update
8. Click Deploy
9. Now you will see requests going for both address A and B on wireshark untill the application is restarted
10. After restarting, requests only go to address B

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: v2.2.2
- Platform/OS: Siemens Simatic IOT2050

title: MQTT node may not show disconnected for a long time when network is disconnected
body:
### Current Behavior

On one of my systems I have four remote mqtt brokers in use.  If I disconnect the network connection to the machine then after about 1 minute the status on three of the MQTT nodes changes to disconnected, and in the node red log I see disconnected messages.  However on one of them the status does not change, even after several minutes, and there is no message in the log.
**Edit**  In fact it does eventually show disconnected, in the log and in the browser, after about 16 minutes.

When I reconnect the network then I see a Disconnected message and then a Connected message.
All the config nodes are configured the same, the only difference with the failing one is that it requires a user/pwd to login, though whether that is significant I do not know.  It also has LWT configured, but so does does one of the others.  The brokers are all mosquitto.

If I stop the remote mosquitto then I see Disconnected immediately. 

This is the config
![image](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/38307/b9716edc-94e0-4b74-a2a2-552a0404ff7e)

A user on the forum has reported a similar problem, though in that case it appears that the messages do not appear even when the network is reconnected. https://discourse.nodered.org/t/detecting-disconnection-of-mqtt-out-node/83914
**Edit**  The OP in the forum post has confirmed that he is not using name/pwd so it seems likely that that is not a factor.

### Expected Behavior

The nodes should show disconnected.

### Steps To Reproduce

See above

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.1.3
- Node.js version: 20.5.1
- npm version:
- Platform/OS: Laptop/Ubuntu 22.04
- Browser: Edge

The user on the forum is using nodejs 18 on a Pi

title: Jsonata editor test error with transform function (3.1.3)
body:
### Current Behavior

I have just updated a node-red server to 3.1.3 and have notice a bug in the JSONata test enviroment in the change node editor.

Prior to update 3.1 this used to work fine.

If you set an array of objects in payload in the test window
```
{
    "payload": [
        {
            "w1": "This",
            "w2": "is",
            "w3": "Big!"
        },
        {
            "w1": "Big",
            "w2": "as",
            "w3": "this?"
        }
    ]
}
```
Then use this expression containing the transform function
```
$$.payload ~> |$|
 {"a":"a"}
|
```
An error is reported

Error evaluating expression:

        }

}

title: Bug in function editor (Cannot redeclare block-scoped variable)
body:
### Current Behavior

In function nodes when declaring variables with same name in "On Start" and "On Message" tabs the editor will underline the variable names and show the error message "Cannot redeclare block-scoped variable".
This happens with "var", "let" and "const".
When finishing the function node with "OK" button there will be a red dot on the function indicating an error. When deploying there is a warning before it's actually deployed.
But it still works perfectly so it's mainly an annoying/cosmetical issue.
This issue is not reproducible by everyone, see here: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/bug-in-function-editor-cannot-redeclare-block-scoped-variable/83937
The bug has been out there for ages, I guess since beginning of v3. In the forum one reported it on 3.0.2 and node 20.

### Expected Behavior

Variables with identical names can be declared in both "On Start" and "On Message" without throwing errors.

### Steps To Reproduce

![nr bug](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/61519363/317ff662-1f38-48f3-ae6e-570d1f58fa2a)


### Example flow

```
[
    {
        "id": "3c780662f9dd4911",
        "type": "function",
        "z": "deb9ccecbf2319fe",
        "name": "function 50",
        "func": "let test=1;\n",
        "outputs": 1,
        "timeout": 0,
        "noerr": 1,
        "initialize": "let test=1;\n",
        "finalize": "",
        "libs": [],
        "x": 530,
        "y": 240,
        "wires": [
            []
        ]
    }
]
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.1.3
- Node.js version: 18.19.0
- npm version: 10.2.3
- Platform/OS: Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS (GNU/Linux 5.4.0-169-generic x86_64)
- Browser: Firefox 121 and Chrome 120
(a lot other Node.js, Node RED and browser versions have been reported to be affected, see linked forum post)

title: Add support of typeField property validation message
body: - [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ## Proposed changes This PR is an extension of #4449 and was discussed inside. If an input is builded with typedInput and contains the typeField option: ```js $("#node-input-path").typedInput({ default: "str", typeField: "#node-input-pathType", types: ["str", "msg"], }); ``` and node properties contains a validator for typeField: ```js defaults: { path: { value: "", ... }, pathType: { value: "str", validate: RED.validators.regex(/^str$/), ... }, ... } ``` This PR adds a validation tooltip message to the field if the typeField validation is not correct. In the example, validation only accepts the type `str` not `msg`: Note: the message on the screenshot is not the message that the example should produce ## Checklist - [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team. - [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass - [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Allow node-red to load nodes with .cjs file extension
body:
<!--
## Before you hit that Submit button....

Please read our [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
before submitting a pull-request.

## Types of changes

What types of changes does your code introduce?
Put an `x` in the boxes that apply
-->

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

<!--
If you want to raise a pull-request with a new feature, or a refactoring
of existing code, it **may well get rejected** if it hasn't been discussed on
the [forum](https://discourse.nodered.org) or
[slack team](https://nodered.org/slack) first.

-->

Fixes #4431

Updates the loader to no-longer assume that the node file always `.js` as a file extension for the javascript.

`.cjs` files work without issue, but previously node-red would try to load a **template** called `file-name.cjs` instead of `file-name.html`, which meant nodes would be missing from the palette despite showing as loaded in settings.

Templates failing to load are silently ignored, in case a node has no associated template, so no error would be displayed but there would be no front-end node available: https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/0589e1f4700d19d44bcd5612e11ec9e5d8b3734d/packages/node_modules/@node-red/registry/lib/loader.js#L215-L224

## Before

For example node from #4431 (https://github.com/Pezmc/node-red-test-node)

![Screenshot 2023-11-10 at 18 32 26](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/507155/749984eb-b1c3-4bff-b6ce-f9cfcb812587)

![Screenshot 2023-11-10 at 18 32 33](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/507155/c77ae27d-433a-40d0-ac06-2361cb094096)

## After

![Screenshot 2023-11-10 at 18 21 04](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/507155/ca0461d2-2a93-4740-bbfe-d7f6ba9d1aff)

![Screenshot 2023-11-10 at 18 32 01](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/507155/a2538c36-b4f5-4bb3-9305-d509fabc1cdd)

## Proposed changes

title: Websocket node can get stuck in CONNECTING state
body:
### Current Behavior

I have a websocket-in node in connect-to mode.

The device it connects to was down this morning and while the device is up again, the node still shows "disconnected".

I wanted to investigate the issue a bit, so I went looking at [the source](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/22-websocket.js) and I found that there is indeed code for automatic reconnect.

Being a bit stumped I randomly tried adding an inject node and a websocket-out node that connects to the same websocket client. I deployed it (in "modified flows" mode) and when I clicked the inject node, I got this error:

```
An error occurred while sending:  Error: WebSocket is not open: readyState 0 (CONNECTING)
```

### Expected Behavior

Ideally the node would just run into a timeout and automatically try to reconnect.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: v3.1.0 (Docker image `nodered/node-red:3.1-debian` started Oct 16)

- Platform/OS: Raspberry Pi OS 64 bit + Docker

title: Node with .cjs suffix does not load properly
body:
### Current Behavior

If a node uses the `.cjs` file extension, node-red appears to try and load it (it shows up in the setting palette), but it is not available in the list of nodes:

Example config:

```javascript
  "node-red": {
    "nodes": {
      "common-js-lower-case": "lower-case-cjs.cjs",
      "esm-lower-case": "lower-case-mjs.mjs",
      "js-lower-case": "lower-case-js.js"
    }
}
```

Note that .cjs and .js appear to have been loaded (and .mjs fails with an ESM error, as expected):

![Screenshot 2023-11-10 at 16 24 14](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/507155/a1f20b57-aa2e-45dc-866c-77810be1d6aa)

However, only .js is available in the list:

![Screenshot 2023-11-10 at 16 23 24](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/507155/05010642-08e6-4c56-a203-83ee9ff2c460)

### Expected Behavior

Files with the .cjs file extension should behave exactly the same as ones with `.js`, i.e. load correctly and slow in the node list.

I suspect something in the loader is trying to load a `.js` file regardless of the node-red config in the package.json; but there are no visible error messages.

### Steps To Reproduce

Repo with issue: https://github.com/Pezmc/node-red-test-node

n/a

title: Bug? Case sensitivity in resources folder for custom nodes
body:
### Current Behavior

I think that case sensitivity was raised a while back because there is a disjoint between how ExpressJS is set up to handle it and how Socket.IO handles it. [Ref](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/4373)

However, I think this might be a slightly different case.

I'm creating a new "dummy" node as a playground for custom node ideas. I want to have this as a scoped module in case I ever actually publish it. The [docs]() show how to add custom resources using the `resources` folder in your package. 

Without thinking, I put "TotallyInformation" as the scope (Pascal Case). This does not work.

Node-RED converts any request URI to lower case it seems and while this works for the base name "Node-RED-Testbed" in this case (yes with the case!) which is lower-cased and works fine, the scope name does not work when lower-cased.

So this link in the node's html file should work and does work if you enter it into the browser manually:

```
<link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet" href="./resources/@TotallyInformation/node-red-testbed/ti-testbed.css" media="all">
```

But that url is converted in Node-RED to "./resources/@totallyinformation/node-red-testbed/ti-testbed.css" which does not work.

Changing the scope name to lower-case does, of course work. However, this must surely be considered a bug? And a very confusing one as well since it is almost impossible to debug unless you have the experience to know about casing issues. And even then, you have to go through lots of trial and error to find an answer since Node-RED does not publish its list of available endpoints.

Bug?

### Expected Behavior

Both the scope part and the node package name part of the URL should behave the same way. Ideally, both should be case sensitive to match W3C recommendations and the behaviour of Socket.IO.

Additionally, the resource URL's should not lower-case the inputs but leave them as entered in the package's `resources` folder.

### Steps To Reproduce

- Create a new GitHub package defining a dummy node.
- Add a resources folder and add a resource file. Try making the file name mixed case.
- Add a reference to the resource in the node's html file.
- Define the package name in package.json with an @scope where the scope name and the package names are mixed case.
- Manually deploy to a Node-RED instance.
- Attempt to access the generated resource URL (can be done from the browser). Note that you cannot access the resource.
- Open the Node-RED Editor and open the browser dev tools. Reload the page and observe that there is a 404 error against the resource URL and that the URL has been set to all lower-case.

Change the package.json name field to be all lower-case and rerun the above tests noting that it all now works.

### Example flow

Not required. However, you can use my dummy playground node to do the testing. It is currently set to have all lower-case naming in package.json but you can manually change your installation to see the issue.

https://github.com/TotallyInformation/Node-RED-Testbed


### Environment

- Node-RED version: Latest
- Node.js version: v18
- npm version: N/A
- Platform/OS: Windows 11
- Browser: Edge

title: STATUS node - number of monitored nodes not reducing when node deleted.
body:
### Current Behavior

I was told to post here.

Ok, here it is. I hope this is the right place.

I couldn't find a BUG REPORT section.

STATUS node.

I was writing code and changed it to selected nodes rather than the default all.

Did some work. Deleted some code - and one of the monitored nodes.

To digress: If I ADD nodes, the number increases as I add them.
Press DEPLOY and all is good.

I delete any of the nodes and the number does NOT reduce.

I have to open the STATUS node (do nothing) and when I close the edit window ONLY THEN does the number reduce.

Picture sequence to view:  1 --> 7.
I hope it shows you the problem.

![1](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/39888280/15b145b5-8be8-436b-bafd-707700de1d1b)
![2](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/39888280/267d1e2a-8bb8-4c91-b72a-ade1b3c35b14)
![3](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/39888280/72c6bfde-d923-4551-984f-3c5f71f7798f)
![4](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/39888280/54202c48-c8b2-49c3-8a79-58c07d1d3872)
![5](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/39888280/90cb93a2-6771-4597-beb7-56d1119a624d)
![6](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/39888280/18db4502-871b-4999-860c-a8007fe7a151)
![7](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/39888280/725120e2-19fc-43b0-b68e-66bc3a712879)


### Expected Behavior

Picture 5 shows the number of monitored nodes has increased from 5 to 6.

Picture 6 is where I delete one of the nodes.
I also press DEPLOY.

Picture 7 shows the `STATUS` node still showing `6` nodes being *tracked*.

To fix it, all I need to do is open the `STATUS` node and close it.
Then the number reduces from 6 to 5.

### Steps To Reproduce

Sorry, see above.

### Example flow

Not really needed.

### Environment

- Node-RED version:  3.0.2
- Node.js version:  16.20.2
- npm version:  8.19.4
- Platform/OS:  Ubuntu 22.04 LTS
- Browser:   FF 119.0

title: let icons be settable by loading from server endpoint
body: - [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ## Proposed changes This PR lets editor node icons be createable (eg from a library) rather than purely static. They are only created at load time (so not fully dynamic... it's not a dashboard after all :-) . They can then be set in the html file by creating an admin endpoint eg (using th feather-icons package RED.httpAdmin.get('/simple/icon/:id', (req, res) => { const sym = req.params.id.split('.')[0]; res.writeHead(200, { "Content-Type": "image/svg+xml" }); res.write(feather.icons[sym].toSvg({width:24, height:24, viewBox:'-4 -4 32 32'})); res.end(); }); and then called by something like icon: function() {return '/simple/icon/' + this.name + '.svg' }, In this PR the server side does expect the node.type (in the lines above = example) and to end with .svg - but this can be discussed changed in the PR... eg it could also be extended to allow .png - but creating dynamic png would be harder... NOTE: it does mean that the get function above must return an SVG of suitable size - ie about 35-40px wide. ## Checklist - [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team. - [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass - [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Fix Node-RED URL case sensitivity for http-in/-out?
body:
### Current Behavior

From: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/fix-node-red-url-case-sensitivity-for-http-in-out/81688

---

Hi devs.

Following this discussion: [Uibuilder and URL case sensitivity - General - Node-RED Forum (nodered.org)](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/uibuilder-and-url-case-sensitivity/81019/5), [@annuello](https://discourse.nodered.org/u/annuello) spotted that Node-RED does not follow the W3C guidelines on the use of case sensitivity in URL's.

This is because the default in ExpressJS also does not use case sensitivity.

Really, this isn't quite in alignment with the standards which say that it SHOULD (not MUST).

More critically, the [Socket.IO](http://socket.io/) library IS case sensitive and as can be seen from the thread, this can cause at least confusion.

So this is an initial request to see if the default could be changed. However, I recognise that this could only happen in a Major version change as it would be potentially breaking.

Thoughts?

Many thanks, J.

### Expected Behavior

Would be better for URL case sensitivity for both ExpressJS and Socket.IO to match. It would be best to align them with W3C recommendations.

### Steps To Reproduce

See https://discourse.nodered.org/t/uibuilder-and-url-case-sensitivity/81019

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: Any
- Node.js version: Any
- npm version: Any
- Platform/OS: Any
- Browser: Any

title: Error "unable to get local issuer certificate" on SSO login attempt
body:
### Current Behavior

We are hosting Node-Red (node-red:3.0.2-16) on multiple of our Kubernetes clusters.

We have configured SSO via configuration on the "/data/settings.js" configuration file. Below is the SSO configuration:

```
    adminAuth: process.env.SSO_ENABLED ? {
        type: "strategy",
        strategy: {
            name: "azuread-openidconnect",
            label: 'Sign in with Microsoft',
            icon: "fa-windows",
            strategy: require("passport-azure-ad").OIDCStrategy,
            options: {
                identityMetadata: "https://login.microsoftonline.com/" + process.env.TENANTID + "/v2.0/.well-known/openid-configuration",
                clientID: process.env.CLIENTID,
                clientSecret: process.env.CLIENTSECRET,
                responseType: "code",
                responseMode: "query",
                redirectUrl: "https://" + process.env.HOSTNAME + "/auth/strategy/callback",
                allowHttpForRedirectUrl: true,
                scope: ['email', 'profile'],
                verify: function (profile, done) {
                    profile.username = profile._json.preferred_username;
                    done(null, profile);
                }
            },
        },
        users: function (user) {
            return Promise.resolve({ username: user, permissions: "*" });
        }
    } : undefined,
```

The needed App Registration for SSO was created on Azure and is all fine.

On accessing Node-Red via its URL, and then on clicking "Sign in with Microsoft", we get the error "unable to get local issuer certificate":

![image](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/75415116/fa758d82-426a-4aa3-9749-e55b36b11e54)

![image](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/75415116/08c41c08-8901-47a3-a791-a33a609b54a8)


On clicking the "Sign in with Microsoft" button multiple times, it then starts working and I am redirected to the SSO login page.

Once it works for me, it then works for other users as well.

After some hours/days, it stops working again with the same behavior.

We have not been able to find a pattern or understand when it works and when it does not. Sometimes, clicking the Sign in button multiple times does not work at all.

Note: We have also a case opened with Microsoft Azure Support to see if the issue is in anyway linked with redirect URL or anything else with SSO authentication. So far, there has been no issues found with authentication.
MS Azure support confirms that there is nothing wrong at IdP and that it is an issue at the application level and that we should contact the application provider.

Hence, we are posting the issue here and hoping for answers from the maintainers and community if anyone has seen this problem before and know of a solution.

Please let me know in case more details are neded.

### Expected Behavior

Clicking on the Sign in button should redirect to the SSO login page.

### Steps To Reproduce

Just launch the URL and click on "Sign in with Microsoft" button. However, as mentioned above, the issue is not always reproducible as it is unexpected when the issue will occur.

### Example flow

![image](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/75415116/fa758d82-426a-4aa3-9749-e55b36b11e54)

![image](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/assets/75415116/08c41c08-8901-47a3-a791-a33a609b54a8)

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.0.2-16
- Node.js version: 16.20.1
- npm version: NA
- yarn:1.22.19
- Platform/OS: Kubernetes v1.24.9 (kubeadm), Ubuntu 20.04
- Browser: Google Chrome
- Base Image: https://hub.docker.com/layers/nodered/node-red/3.0.2-16/images/sha256-e2cd6b89e18361593276e3ef5282b403e0879040c96d3099c15e8f0200a36339?context=explore

title: The edit description sidebar popup closes unexpectedly while selecting text.
body:
### Current Behavior

When you go to the Edit description sidebar popup and select text, if you continue dragging your mouse outside the window into the grayed out main window it will closes the description popup sidebar without warning.

### Expected Behavior

When I'm selecting text in the edit description, I should be able to select text without accidentally closing the window.  I don't expect anything to "close" the window unless I click the "done", "cancel" or click in the grayed out window.

1. Double click any node.
2. Click the "Description" icon
3. Write some text in description
4. Select that text with the mouse, and keep holding mouse button until it drifts outside the box into the grayed out window then let go of mouse button.

title: Add support for installing ESM module nodes
body:
- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

Currently node-red fails when attempting to install a node written as an ESM module, e.g.

```text
19 Sep 18:59:53 - [info] Server now running at http://127.0.0.1:1880/
19 Sep 18:59:53 - [info] Starting flows
19 Sep 18:59:53 - [info] Started flows
19 Sep 19:01:05 - [info] Installing module: @hlovdal/node-red-lowercase-in-typescript, version: 1.0.0
19 Sep 19:01:12 - [info] Installed module: @hlovdal/node-red-lowercase-in-typescript
19 Sep 19:01:12 - [info] Added node types:
19 Sep 19:01:12 - [info]  - @hlovdal/node-red-lowercase-in-typescript:lower-case : Error [ERR_REQUIRE_ESM]: require() of ES Module .../.node-red/node_modules/@hlovdal/node-red-lowercase-in-typescript/src/lower-case.js from .../node-red/packages/node_modules/@node-red/registry/lib/loader.js not supported.
Instead change the require of lower-case.js in .../node-red/packages/node_modules/@node-red/registry/lib/loader.js to a dynamic import() which is available in all CommonJS modules.
```

This pull request fixes that by using [dynamic `import()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/import) instead of `require`.

## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the [forum](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/adding-support-for-installing-esm-module-nodes/81438)/slack team.
- [x] I have run `npm run test` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Add support for global httpNode middleware
body:
The current `httpNodeMiddleware` option only gets applied to the HTTP nodes and any other 3rd party nodes that have opted into using it.

Node-RED Dashboard uses a different settings option to provide a custom middleware.

We don't have a single option that will be applied consistently across *all* non-admin routes.

The proposal here is to add `httpNodeGlobalMiddleware` as an option that will get applied at the top level mounting of the node-side express app.

As with `httpNodeMiddleware` this will support being a function or array of functions.

title: Uninstalling (via CLI) an unused and disabled node leaves it visible in palette manager.
body:
### Current Behavior

If an unused node module, which is disabled in palette manager, is uninstalled using npm command line, and node-red restarted, then the node is still shown as installed in the palette manager.

### Expected Behavior

It should disappear from the palette manager installed nodes.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Install a node using the palette manager
2. Disable the node using the palette manager
3. Uninstall the node using npm from the command line
4. Restart node-red
5. Refresh the browser page
6. Look in palette manager where the node is still shown as installed and disabled
7. Attempting to remove it in the palette manager fails (module not found)

The situation can be recovered by installing it again using the command line, restarting node-red, and removing it using palette manager.

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.0.2, and 3.1.0-beta.4
- Node.js version: 18 and 20
- npm version:
- Platform/OS: Windows 11 and Ubuntu 22.04
- Browser: Edge

title: Plugins that don't carry nodes aren't shown - despite installed - in the Palette Manager
body:
As explained by @knolleary in [this forum post](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/some-nodes-not-showing-in-manage-palette/76817/2?u=ralphwetzel), plugins that don't carry nodes aren't shown - despite installed - in the Palette Manager.

Consequentially, such a plugin can be _installed_ - yet it can **neither be updated nor removed** via this mean.

I'm intending to raise a PR to overcome this limitation:
The objective would be to integrate those kind of plugins into the list of "Installed Nodes". Once done, this label might not be 100% correct anymore - but changing it should be subject of a separate discussion.

title: parsers/70-HTML.js - node html extract encoding problems
body:
### Current Behavior

When we extract an html containing accent characters, we receive from cheerio, an encoding html .

Ã¨ -> é

Solution : 
Adding an option for decodeentities Y/N (for cheerio.load() options)

change in code : 
```
cheerio.load($(this).html().trim(),null,false).xml()
```
by
```
cheerio.load($(this).html().trim(),{ decodeEntities: false },false).xml()
```


more info about cheerio options: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31574127/node-js-cheerio-parser-breaks-utf-8-encoding

### Expected Behavior

Expected behavior could be to not change the original encoding 

### Steps To Reproduce

Scrap an html with accent charaters 
extract an outerhtml from an element

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

all version

title: NODE install through API taking too long for some nodes in offline environment
body:
### Current Behavior

we are trying to install nodes with the help of admin api present in the documentation (https://nodered.org/docs/api/admin/methods/post/nodes/), its working fine but, we cant predict its behavior i.e for some nodes its installing very fast but for some it's taking way too long,(~20 min). But as soon as we switch on the internet the wait time reduce significantly. 

API IMPLIEMTATION :  curl -F tarball=@/PATH-FOR-TGZ-NPM-PACK --request POST -H "Authorization: Bearer {TOKEN}" http://IP-address:1880/nodes

*NOTE : Please enable user login to get the token using this api : 
curl --request POST --data 'client_id=node-red-admin&grant_type=password&scope=*&username={your-email}&password={your-password}' http://IP-ADDRESS:1880/auth/token



### Expected Behavior

should install nodes fast or in reasonable times

### Steps To Reproduce

1) install node-red
2) try installing a node with .tgz npm pack online using node-red api mentioned above, and observe the time it takes to install.
3) cut off the internet try the same as step (2)  
4) you see a significantly difference in time to install the node.

```
paste your flow here
```

- Node.js version: v14.18.2
- npm version:

title: Documentation Improvement?
body:
In securing Node-Red, https://nodered.org/docs/user-guide/runtime/securing-node-red, there's what I feel is either an error, or an item that could be improved.

The TLS setup calls for the entry of references to the installation's privkey.pem and cert.pem files to be entered in the file settings.js.

cert.pm carries only the site certificate for a node-red installation. This permits secured communication with the server, but only using the site certificate to verify authenticity. Site certificates change with each certificate renewal, so only last a short time.

By changing the reference to cert.pem, to fullkey.pem, you're then able to authenticate with the certificate of the root certificate signing authority associated with your node-red's site certificate. These last, in some cases, decades, and authenticating against them will reduce the need to so frequently update the certificates burned into your accessing devices' firmware.

I've tested the change with Node-RED version: v3.0.2, and Node.js  version: v16.20.0, and it works fine. One then has the choice of (from least favourable to most) no certificate, site certificate fingerprint, site public key, site certificate, intermediary certificate, and root signing authority certificate authentication.

title: MQTT stops receiving messages, but can publish
body: ### Current Behavior I've got both NodeRed (`v2.2.2`) and MQTT running in docker containers, hosted locally. - Everything was running fine for months but suddenly stopped receiving messages from MQTT - verified with this simple flow, this did not output anything to the debug console: - At the same time, it was able to publish messages to the same MQTT with no issues - tried it several hundred times (literally) and verified it on the MQTT console. - Other application were communicating fine via MQTT, for example zigbee2mqtt was fine both receiving and publishing. - Restarting the MQTT server did not help. **All the above** lead me to the conclusion that the problem must be in NodeRED. I restarted NodeRED and everything started working fine. I've got NodeRED logs, but theres a lot of them, I'm not sure if they are useful. Any hints on how to debug this? ### Expected Behavior NodeRed should receive messages from MQTT. ### Steps To Reproduce Happens randomly, can't reproduce. ### Example flow Just print out all MQTT messages. ### Environment - Node-RED version: 2.2.2 from Docker Hub - Node.js version: (as on Docker Hub) - npm version: (as on Docker Hub) - Platform/OS: docker image from Docker Hub - Browser: Chrome on macOS

title: MQTT V5 retain flag options not working correctly if two MQTT In nodes on same topic with different settings.
body:
### Current Behavior

With two MQTT In nodes configured to subscribe to the same (retained) topic on a V5 broker (mosquitto), if one is configured to Not keep retained flag, and the other is configured Keep retained flag, then in fact it is kept on both.

Note that there appears to be a second bug, that if the Keep option is changed in the MQTT In node, it is necessary to restart the flows in order for that to take. So when testing this use Full Deploy. 

See also the forum post https://discourse.nodered.org/t/understanding-mqtt-v5-retain-options/77118

### Expected Behavior

Whether to keep the flag should be as configured for each node.

### Steps To Reproduce

Import the flow below and deploy (it expects a V5 broker at localhost), and uses the topic test/testretained.

Click the Inject. Debug 99 should show msg.retain false, but it is true.

title: Locally installed nodered on macos stops sending udp packets after sleep
body:
### Current Behavior

If you create an udp sender node and connect an injector to it that sends a message once per second, and then close the laptop lid for a few hours afterwards, when the node wakes up it will stop sending messages despite no errors


I used the following code to check that I received the messages:
```
import socket

def start_udp_server(host, port):
    with socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM) as server_socket:
        server_socket.bind((host, port))
        print(f"UDP server listening on {host}:{port}")
        while True:
            data, addr = server_socket.recvfrom(1024)
            print(f"Received data: {data.decode()} from {addr}")

host = "localhost"
port = 8889

try:
    start_udp_server(host, port)
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    print("\nServer stopped")
```

### Expected Behavior

_No response_

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Example flow

```
[
    {
        "id": "a0640be951b0b6cb",
        "type": "udp out",
        "z": "7caf6ca843f60c6e",
        "name": "",
        "addr": "127.0.0.1",
        "iface": "",
        "port": "8889",
        "ipv": "udp4",
        "outport": "",
        "base64": false,
        "multicast": "broad",

        "y": 3380,
        "wires": []
    },
    {
        "id": "929437f7ec4598f9",

        "props": [
            {
                "p": "payload"

                "p": "topic",

        "repeat": "6",

title: Issue modifying globals set in functionGlobalContext
body:
### Current Behavior

I've encountered a strange behaviour where if I set an object in functionGlobalContext and modify it after in Node-RED, I will get unexpected behaviour.  
If I add properties to the object and then delete those properties and try to access them using an inject (for example global.foo.myproperty)
The property is still there (even though it's not there in the sidebar.

I attached a flow that is easy to reproduce, this assumes your settings file has this:

```
module.exports = {
    exportGlobalContextKeys: true,
    functionGlobalContext: {
        foo: {hello: 24}
    }
}
```

### Expected Behavior

title: ERR_SOCKET_DGRAM_NOT_RUNNING in UDP out
body:
### Current Behavior

I am using node-red to successfully send Syslog messages via UDP, buy means of a workflow that includes:
node-red-contrib-syslog and standard UDP out.

The system works fine, but it will start failing after some days. 

Re-deploying the flows makes it come back to life.

### Expected Behavior

UDP out should continue to work

### Steps To Reproduce

install node-red docker
create a subworkflow for syslog using:
- node-red-contrib-syslog
- udp out.
use the sub-workflow to log via SYSLOG one message per day, for example.
after several days no syslog messages are received: ERR_SOCKET_DGRAM_NOT_RUNNING is being logged.

title: Documentation is incorrect
body:
### Current Behavior

The page [here](https://nodered.org/docs/creating-nodes/first-node) states the following:

> To test a node module locally the [npm install <folder>](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/install) command can be used. This allows you to develop the node in a local directory and have it linked into a local node-red install during development.

Following these instructions the test node did not show up in the palette.

### Expected Behavior

The above information is incorrect as the `settings.json` file states that:

> Node-RED scans the `nodes` directory in the userDir to find local node files.

I have renamed the `node_modules` directory to `node` in `~/.node-red` and can confirm that it works.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

title: msg produces [object Object] while it is exists
body: ### Current Behavior Forum [reference](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/flow-context-object-object-while-it-exists/76339). A Node produces an object: ``` {"_msgid":"4f8593f35411a605","payload":1678362753578,"topic":"","browser":{"session":"f90af67ca05620ea5a0aa4dc922df9a3","_webdriver":{"_serverURL":"http://localhost:9515/","_api":{}},"_closed":false,"browserType":"chrome","timeouts":{"implicit":0,"pageLoad":300000,"script":30000}}} ``` Using a change node: `flow.browser` = `msg.browser` `flow.browser` is stored in context as `[object Object]` The context does exist when reading it, however when using an inject node: `msg.payload` = `flow.browser` produces: `[object Object]` - when the debug node is set to output `msg.payload`. Changing the debug to display the `complete msg object` -`msg.payload` produces a correct object. (**note**: where does the "Browser" word come from in the msg.payload output ?) ### Expected Behavior Expected to see an object in flow.browser context and when the debug is set to display `msg.payload` : ``` {"browser":{"session":"f90af67ca05620ea5a0aa4dc922df9a3","_webdriver":{"_serverURL":"http://localhost:9515/","_api":{}},"_closed":false,"browserType":"chrome","timeouts":{"implicit":0,"pageLoad":300000,"script":30000}} ``` ### Steps To Reproduce It does not occur when sending msg.payload with the object directly. I am not able to reproduce it in another way: To repoduce it requires chromium, chromedriver and the [node-red-contrib-simple-webdriver](https://github.com/simonradier/node-red-contrib-simple-webdriver) node. Open a url using the "open browser" node and from its 'succes' output, connect a change node, set `flow.browser` to `msg.browser`. Verify the context. ### Example flow _No response_ ### Environment - Node-RED version: 3.0.2 - Node.js version: v18.14.2 - npm version:9.5.0 - Platform/OS: Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye) - Browser: MacOS/Safari Version 16.1 (17614.2.9.1.13, 17614)

title: Latched/retained topics and multiple "mqtt in" nodes that share a broker
body:
### Current Behavior

If you have two (or more) `mqtt in` nodes that use the same broker connection, and they subscribe to the same topic, and that topic is "latched" (aka the latest message is "retained", i.e., clients get the latest message when they connect), then only one of the `mqtt in` nodes gets the latched topic message.

### Expected Behavior

Since `mqtt in` nodes can share a broker connection (and it would seem a little cumbersome to have multiple broker connections to the same MQTT server), it is reasonable to expect that each `mqtt in` node would behave as if it were the only one.  I would therefore expect the broker node to retain "latched" messages so that `mqtt in` nodes that subsequently subscribe to a latched topic can also expect to receive the latched message (after the topic's latched message has been sent to its first subscribing `mqtt in` node).

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create an MQTT broker connection node.
2. Create two `mqtt in` nodes.
3. Subscribe each of them to the same latched topic.
4. Only the first subscriber receives the latched message, but both receive subsequent messages.

title: http-request node: Incorrect implementation of proxy with keep-alive
body:
### Current Behavior

When using http-request node with proxy and keep-alive,
The node opens **new** connection (- create new instance of http-agent) in each request 
instead of using same connection for all the requests.
As the connection is really kept alive but not used again, it cause a lot of open and unused connections. 

### Expected Behavior

Use one http-agent instance which is managing the connections and implement reuse of connections in case of keep-alive.

Deeping to the code:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/125454784/219006267-cb296cd3-4252-49aa-9355-19f61d349c54.png)
these lines creatign new instance of HttpProxyAgent and HttpsProxyAgent in each request. 
Should create these instances one and reuse it in each request.

### Steps To Reproduce

Create simple flow with http-request node with proxy (in my case the proxy set in HTTPS_PROXY environment variable).
Execute the http-request several times in a row (may use inject node with interval option enabled)
Use TCPDUMP or other tool to follow network connections.

### Example flow

```
