Error when trying to pull from remote private repo
body:
### Current Behavior

Same as #3494

I've create a private gitlab repo, self-hosted.
Push from nodered to repo are fine.
pull gives error, both in stdout and a popup in ui.
`11 Feb 17:04:39 - [error] TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'fetch')
`

Manual git pull from cli inside the container work.
```
export GIT_SSH_COMMAND="ssh -o IdentitiesOnly=yes -i /data/projects/.sshkeys/admin_gitlab"
cd /data/projects/BBrose/
git pull
Updating 1dbf520..46cb728
Fast-forward
 flows.json | 7 +++++++
 1 file changed, 7 insertions(+)
```
I just have to restart the flow to apply the changes


### Expected Behavior

pull successful

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create a new project
2. Create a repo on GitHub
3. Add the repo to Git remotes
4. Add nodes to a flow
5. Commit the changes
6. Push the code to the remote repo
7. Make changes on the remote repo
8. Refresh commit history
9. Pull changes

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.0.2 from docker image
- Node.js version: v16.16.0
- npm version: 8.11.0 
- Platform/OS: Docker 
- Browser: Chrome / linux desktop

title: cred input does not work after package it from subflow to node
Node Red Won't Load
Join node remembering additional properties from previous messages
body:
### Current Behavior

If a Join node in key/value mode is given a message with additional properties, and then given a message without those properties, then the properties from the first message may be passed on to the output.

### Expected Behavior

A message passed on should be exactly the message passed in, with only msg.payload replaced.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Import the flow below and deploy it.
2. Click the Inject node `A:timestamp msg.full:true`
3. Note in the debug node that the message correctly has msg.full present.
4. Click the Inject node `A:timestamp No msg.full`
5. Note that the message still has msg.true present, which it should not.

### Example flow

```
[{"id":"bb68bb3693e0d1f1","type":"inject","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"A:timestamp  No msg.full","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"A","payload":"","payloadType":"date","x":210,"y":3200,"wires":[["f9e9e10d41b65ca1"]]},{"id":"30e24e64b1b57f52","type":"inject","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"B","payload":"","payloadType":"date","x":230,"y":3340,"wires":[["f9e9e10d41b65ca1"]]},{"id":"a99c557ae2cf9bfc","type":"inject","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"A:timestamp   msg.full:true","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"},{"p":"full","v":"true","vt":"bool"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"A","payload":"","payloadType":"date","x":170,"y":3260,"wires":[["f9e9e10d41b65ca1"]]},{"id":"47ac7e6620607619","type":"debug","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"debug 70","active":true,"tosidebar":true,"console":false,"tostatus":false,"complete":"true","targetType":"full","statusVal":"","statusType":"auto","x":700,"y":3260,"wires":[]},{"id":"d4a479ac4ee76c68","type":"join","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"","mode":"custom","build":"object","property":"payload","propertyType":"msg","key":"topic","joiner":"\\n","joinerType":"str","accumulate":true,"timeout":"","count":"1","reduceRight":false,"reduceExp":"","reduceInit":"","reduceInitType":"","reduceFixup":"","x":550,"y":3260,"wires":[["47ac7e6620607619"]]},{"id":"f9e9e10d41b65ca1","type":"junction","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","x":400,"y":3260,"wires":[["d4a479ac4ee76c68"]]}]

title: WebSocket compatibility with Node.js 18.x
body:
### Current Behavior

WebSocket client ("connect to") nodes fail to connect to server ("listen to") nodes when the latter are running under Node.js 18.12.1.

### Expected Behavior

WebSocket connections should work consistently on LTS version of Node.js as well as earlier versions.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Install Node.js LTS
2. Install Node-RED using the standard Debian script without specifying a version of Node.js
3. Create a pair of "listen to" and "connect to" websocket nodes using the corresponding URI and URL values such that they should connect, e.g. "listen to" URI = /test and "connect to" URL = ws://localhost:1880/test

In my case, the latter works when the "listen to" node is running under Node.js 16.x but not when it is running under 18.x. 

If it helps in debugging, "connect to" nodes running under Node.js 18.x do appear able to connect to "listen to" nodes on the network when the "listen to" nodes are running under 16.x. I.e. the issue appears to be on the server side.

### Example flow

        "disabled": false,

title: Context Variables are not shown correctly in the UI
body:
### Current Behavior

I am massivly working with global context variables.
When I set or change variables (does not matter, if its done via function node or a change node). The variables are set correctly and can also be read via a get call. I can also check them for example by looking into the global.json (store).

But the Editors UI is showing totally different values and even structure there is wrong.

If I press the global refresh button the values still do not get updated. If I press the local variable based refresh button, the variable is changing to "undefined".
That very bad because the work with variables is hard to be debugged like this. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20902204/210242483-9918b2d3-8eb9-4017-bd29-fa0aca2a0566.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20902204/210242616-763a54a6-bd29-421f-ab45-247af36f2d53.png)


### Expected Behavior

Expected is that the UI shows the real value and structure of the variables.

### Steps To Reproduce

relevant part of the settings.json (I am only using "default"):

```
    contextStorage: {
        default: { module: "localfilesystem"},
        memory: { module: "memory" }
    },

```

### Example flow

```
paste your flow here
```


### Environment

Docker based installation:

- Node-RED version: v3.0.2
- Node.js version: v16.16.0

title: fix: registry importModule function
body: - [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ## Proposed changes Use `parsedModule.module` instead of `module`, `module` contains the version installed, therefore importing the module results in an error because the folder does not exists in `node_modules`. See screenshot. Bug introduced here > https://github.com/node-red/node-red/pull/3645 ## Checklist - [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [ ] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team. - [x] I have run `grunt` to verify the unit tests pass - [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Incorrect done behavior when mixing streams of String and Buffer with Split node
body:
### Current Behavior

Sending a mix of string and buffer payloads into a streaming split node results in what appears to be incorrect triggering of Complete nodes.

### Expected Behavior

A Complete node should only be triggered for a message after it has been processed. In the case of a Split node, processed means that the input data has been fully output. In the current implementation, it is possible to receive a Complete trigger before the received data is output by the Split node.

### Steps To Reproduce

Use the flow below to see the problem. The (condensed) output is

1.  DONE (string "aa")
2. [0x61]
3. [0x62]
4. [0x62]
5. DONE (with buffer that generated 0x61, 0x62, and 0x63 output)
6. "aa"
7. DONE ??

Output 1 is unexpected as string "aa" hasn't been output until step 6.

The expected output is:

1. [0x61]
2. [0x62]
3. [0x62]
4. DONE (with buffer that generated 0x61, 0x62, and 0x63 output)
5. "aa"
6. DONE (with string that generated "aa")


### Example flow

title: Add msg property `payloadHandling` for setting how a GET request handles payload
body:
## Types of changes

As reported on forum and raised in #3957, the HTTP Request node could not set the payload handling for a get request. 
The option set in the dropdown field before the method was changed to `"use msg.method"` and hidden would be used causing confusion to user.

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

As described in the issue, this PR adds a `msg` property to permit the user to specify the payload handling via msg.payloadHandling`

Other changes include...
* Update help to include instructions on `msg.payloadHandling` property
* leave the "Payload Handling" dropdown visible for "- set by msg.method -" and "GET" options
* Add an entry to the "Payload Handling" dropdown named "- set by msg.payloadHandling -" to provide a visible cue
![chrome_G5ZVnZO1F5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/204544147-d0a9b1e0-11ef-4e2b-b56e-04f2fa364836.gif)



### Considerations & points of discussion before merging...
1. ~~Although setting body in a GET request is VERY uncommon (many web servers even prohibit this) there may be some flows in the wild that work "by accident" (having set the payload handling dropdown to "add payload to body" or "add payload to querystring") BEFORE setting the method dropdown to "Use msg.method".  We may want to use the nodes value OR consider showing the payload handling dropdown & adding a "use msg.payloadHandling" entry?~~
   1.  Updated PR in [3a5cdbc](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/pull/3961/commits/3a5cdbc8ae2e9317b766574e8dd6831d52478aa1)
2. As noted in comments in the tests: Either Express does not deliver the body of a GET request OR GOT doesn't send it! That means we cannot test this!  Oddly, if the HTTP-Req node sets `options.json` instead of `options.body` when making the request, then the body is delivered! I was curious if this ever worked and fired up Node-RED v1.3.7 (using REQUEST instead of GOT) & it seems it may be express discarding the `body`.  I have no way to prove this works other than to say, if the `allowGetBody` option is **NOT** set and we include a `body`, we get the error `The 'GET' method cannot be used with a body`!  So we can only assume it works.


## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [x] I have run `grunt` to verify the unit tests pass
- [x] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: [http-request] : Can't set payload handling when method is passed in via `msg.method`
body:
### Current Behavior

When `- set by msg.method -` is used for the method, it hides the payload handling dropdown on the node config editor.
Now then, If the user does not first choose the payload handling option prior to  selecting `- set by msg.method -` 

The users payload is ignored, i.e for GET requests, the payload is not passed in as a query string, as the default is to ignore it.

The user has to first set it back to GET, change the payload handling option, then set it back to `- set by msg.method -`.
The option is there initially, but this could trip up new users.





### Expected Behavior

Iether allow payload handling options to be include in the message, or to not hide the option

### Steps To Reproduce

- Add a new http-request node
- set it to `- set by msg.method -`
- Note that the payload handling option has gone 

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: **3.0.0**
- Node.js version: **16.15.1**
- npm version: **8.11.0**
- Platform/OS: **Debian**
- Browser: **Safari**

Discussed here:
https://discourse.nodered.org/t/http-request-node-returning-error

title: Serial port not working after deploy "Modified Flows"

### Current Behavior

After deploy "Modified Flows" Serial-in not working.

### Expected Behavior

Should work ;-)

### Steps To Reproduce

This is the test environment:
Serial out connects directly to Serial in (null-modem), either a UART or a USB to serial adapter. TxD is connected to RxD.
The inject node sends a string, the debug node displays it. Now the text in the Inject node is changed and applied with deploy "Modified Flows". Serial reception is now broken, but only within Node-Red. Reception works in the OS, as shown by "cat /dev/ttyUSB0".

title: Change node accepts only one "Example message" for JSONata
body:
### Current Behavior

Create a change node with two rules, setting "msg.test1" and "msg.test2" to JSONata values "1" and "2" (just for demo purposes).
Go in to the "Test" tab for the first and set the "Example message" to:
```
{
    "payload": "test1"
}
```
Go into the second and set it similarly, but using test2. Go back to the first one and have a look - the example message has 'magically' changed to be what's in the second rule.

### Expected Behavior

I expect to be able to put different "Example message" code in each rule on a change node. I'm progressively building up a complex message, so want separate rules, each with their own "Example message". Obviously it works fine if you have two change nodes.

I'm guessing that you're storing the "Example message" with the whole change node, so moving it to the rule might be a breaking change you don't want to deal with. If this is the case, it might be better to move the "Example message" to a tab at the node level (with Properties / Description / Appearance). And then duplicate it on the rule with the title "Node's example message", while still allowing it to be edited. This should make it clear there's only one for the whole node and what you see on the rule is there for convenience (because otherwise it would be a pain toggling back-and-forth until you get your JSONata doing what you want).

### Steps To Reproduce

See above. Although I've pasted the change node below, an export does not include the "Sample message", so you would need to type that part in. It would also be very useful for the "Example message" to be included in an export and ctl-C as I use this a fair bit and copy messages around without realising it will lose the test data.

### Example flow

```
[
    {
        "id": "4fa5dfd99196cfa2",
        "type": "change",
        "z": "e05a6d6980afb4f7",
        "name": "",
        "rules": [
            {
                "t": "set",
                "p": "test1",
                "pt": "msg",
                "to": "1",
                "tot": "jsonata"
            },
            {
                "t": "set",
                "p": "test2",
                "pt": "msg",
                "to": "2",
                "tot": "jsonata"
            }
        ],
        "action": "",
        "property": "",
        "from": "",
        "to": "",
        "reg": false,
        "x": 380,
        "y": 320,
        "wires": [
            []
        ]
    }
]
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: v3.0.0
- Node.js version: v14.16.0
- npm version: 6.14.11
- Platform/OS: Docker/Ubuntu
- Browser: Chrome

_No response_

I created a function node with moment, tried it, it worked. Then added is-date-object and moment stopped working.

title: Cannot reset debug node message counter
body:
As touched on [here](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/issues/3514#issuecomment-1096635545), 

> Resetting the value when the node is restarted is good enough for now. Although I wouldn't lose sleep if it support msg.resetCount as well.

I propose we should implement a means of resetting the debug counter.

title: Join node locking up in manual key/value mode with Timeout
body:
### Current Behavior

With a Join node in Manual,  Key/Value mode and only a Timeout specified, When the first messages are received then, after the timeout, it sends the joined message correctly.  However it then just locks up and never sends anything else, unless msg.reset is sent in, in which case it recovers and will send one more message.

### Expected Behavior

After the timeout and the message is sent then it should wait for more inputs and restart the timer.

### Steps To Reproduce

Import the flow below.
Click one of the Inject buttons,  1 second later the message is sent out.
Click buttons - nothing happens
Click Reset and then one of the inputs and the message is sent correctly

### Example flow

```

title: Add setting to disable tcp/udp server (inbound)
body:
fixes #3902 ## Types of changes - [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ## Proposed changes As per issue #3902 ### TODO 2022/12/04 - [x] ensure it is clear to user why inbound connections are not possible but dont show a the red validation triangle - [x] add settings to default settings.js file - [ ] update node-red-admin settings.js file ### Notes and concerns... (updated 2022/12/04) * Introduces two new settings flags `tcpInAllowInboundConnections` and `udpInAllowInboundConnections` * These settings are exposed to the client side via the in built mechanism for exposing setting to editor (`RED.nodes.registerType("tcp in",TCPin, { settings: {...} }`). However this forces the name of the setting to match the node e.g. `tcpInSomething` or `tcpOutSomething`. For now, `tcpInAllowInboundConnections` was chosen but since it is used for the TCP In and TCP Out it looks a little odd asking users to set `tcpInAllowInboundConnections` for the TCP In and Out nodes? * ~~Alternative: map a _nicer_ setting name through to editor programmatically~~ * ~~Use 2 variables `tcpInAllowInboundConnections` / `tcpOutAllowInboundConnections`~~ * UI elements are deliberately still shown and still accessible (see next point) * ~~It may be better to NOT indicate a design time error since a specific installation may permit these nodes for "offline flow building" (for later export to a remote device)~~ * ~~Alternatively, additional flags of `tcpInValidateAllowInboundConnections` and `udpInValidateAllowInboundConnections` could be employed to turn on/off design time validation~~ * ~~New settings, for now, have deliberately NOT been included in the default settings file (merits to discuss)~~ * Currently, this PR does not introduce the feature(s) via ENV settings since they would need mapping through to the editor (for the requested frontend validation) - until above points are ratified and we speak about these points, I did not want to spend too much time heading in (potentially) the wrong direction :) . ### Screenshots (Updated 2022/12/04) #### TCP ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/205486705-0bd3b842-e9e3-4847-a6db-8a00abcfa8cd.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/205486643-7a8a9c93-fc21-4eda-b79d-a67dd6061946.png) NOTE: The help comment is improved to read: ***NOTE:** If your node shows "inbound connections are disabled", then it has been disabled in the Node-RED settings file.* #### UDP ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/205486748-da061dbe-a059-434f-a3f7-10b96c494f5a.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/205486820-c62ee8b6-ccd7-4815-a3d6-f4b0ea870c4b.png) NOTE: The help comment is improved to read: ***NOTE:** If your node shows "inbound connections are disabled", then it has been disabled in the Node-RED settings file.*

Screenshots (OUTDATED 2022/12/04)

 #### Flow status ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/197969174-0bf5b70a-3db4-4757-bb13-2f8d77766de4.png) #### TCP In node ![chrome_JRR7dRswEI](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/197969310-deda837d-8a7a-4b2d-b302-310ce822a76c.gif) #### TCP Out node ![chrome_5yeMV9V3QV](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/197969350-6b8fb9f5-a717-45b1-a1a9-6ea60f84237e.gif) #### UDP In node ![chrome_5VopnaVcH7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44235289/197969413-07e26ee2-c8ce-404c-be08-621a0f8a7f6c.gif)
## Checklist - [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team. - [x] I have run `grunt` to verify the unit tests pass - [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Read File node in a line at a time mode returns an extra, blank line.
body:
### Current Behavior

GIven this datafile, each line terminated by `\n` (on Linux $ printf "%s\n%s\n" "ONE" "TWO" > testdata)
ONE
TWO

Read File a message per line emits 3 messages "ONE, "TWO" and ""

This is contrary to some other programming languages, at least on Linux. eg C getline() will retrieve 2 lines, so do interpreted languages such as awk and perl.

If the second new line is removed ($ printf "%s\n%s" "ONE" "TWO" > testdata), read File now emits 2 messages "ONE" and "TWO", while the C, awk, perl etc versions still report 2 lines.
NB wc -l is different, it simply counts `\n` characters.

If you pass the 3 messages to a Write File node, add `\n` to each line, the resulting file now has two new lines at the end. 

### Expected Behavior

Both versions of the test data file, with and without a final new line character, should result in two messages, in accordance with other programmatic ways of counting lines.
The final, empty string message is the error

### Steps To Reproduce

See discussion on NR [forum](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/read-file-node-returns-one-line-too-many/68807/14)

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.0.2
- Node.js version: 16.17.0
- npm version: 8.15.0
- Platform/OS: Raspberry Pi/RPiOS
- Browser: Firefox

title: Read file node ignores msg.filename
body:

Setting the full path to a file in msg.filename is ignored by 'read file'. It only works when I set the filename field to msg.filename in the Properties of the 'read file' node. 

The debug panel shows the following error: "No filename specified"

### Expected Behavior

I expect the 'read file' to read the file specified in msg.filename without any further configuration of the 'read file' node.

title: Crash with Client network socket disconnected error
body:
### Current Behavior

I'm running node-red dockerized in docker swarm using this compose snipplet ( so nodered/node-red:latest):

```
  nodered:
    image: nodered/node-red
    container_name: nodered
    hostname: nodered
    user: "1000:1000"
    restart: always
    environment:
      - TZ=Europe/Berlin
    volumes:
      - /home/docker/nodered/data:/data
    links:
      - influxdb
      - mosquitto
    ports:
      - 1880:1880
      - 2048:2048
      - 2049:2049
    labels:
       - swarmpit.service.deployment.autoredeploy=true
    deploy:
      placement:
        constraints:
        - node.role == manager
      resources:
        limits:

        reservations:

```

This happens almost always when I want to start up the stack. Usually the second task is successfull and don't crash.


### Expected Behavior

title: Feature: add settings flag to disable inbound TCP/UDP nodes
body:
In some hosted environments it isn't desirable to expose the core TCP/UDP nodes that allow inbound connections. However, those nodes also support outbound connections - which is supported in hosted environments.

For example, the IBM Cloud hosted instance disabled the TCP/UDP nodes and replaced them with custom nodes that used the same node types, but only supported outbound connections. Those forked nodes then inevitably fell behind the core nodes.

It would be better if the core nodes supported this use case and provided a means (via the settings file) to disable their inbound modes.

title: NodeRed inconsistent config node behavior in subflows
body:
### Current Behavior

When in a subflows there is 2 different "types" of `config` typed nodes :

1. Global, this config node was created outside the subflow and is globally defined
1. Instanciated per-subflow, this config node was created inside this specific subflow (this happens in the example flow, the node `tls-config` with the `234780210e8befa3` id in the `557a7b4568eb82ef` subflow will be instanciated twice)

There is a huge difference in behavior between those two modes that can leads to unexpected behaviors

### Expected Behavior

I believe config nodes should all be 'global' as that's the whole point of making such a node, to share the configuration and avoiding generating multiple instance of it. OR At least to only instanciate it once in the subflow it's used in.

So either the config nodes doesn't get a `z` field and are all global, or a new field specifically for scopping them to one specific `subflows` (allowing to hide the node from the rest of the flows like it does today).

### Steps To Reproduce

Create a subflow, and a node that can have a configuration node within (like `http request` + `tls-config`). instanciate this subflow N times, making it instanciate N tls-config node.

If the config node implements specific authentication mechanism that only enable one authentication to be made at a time, or if it hosts the connection for other node to use then this cause config nodes in subflow to not behave as intended (instead there will be once instance per subflow instance)

title: Junction node not working in editor on touch device
body:
### Current Behavior

I am using an iPad to edit flows, and currently the junction node is not working as expected. Having multiple issues:

- I am unable to select a junction node using touch
- Not being able to move a junction node using touch
- Not being able to connect wires to or from a junction node.

The only way I am able to select a junction node is by selecting all connected nodes (shift + click) and then deselecting the other nodes. Using the keyboard (Shift + arrow keys) I am able to move the junction node then.

With a short tap on the junction, the little input and output connections do appear, but I am unable to draw wires from or to them even then.


### Expected Behavior

- I expect to select a junction node by short tapping it, and then being able to move it and draw wires from and to it.
- I expect a short tap and drag to move the junction around.
- I expect a long tap and drag to be able to draw wires in and out of the junction.

The short and long tap for moving or drawing lines is merely a suggestion of expected behavior, as is common practice in touch interfaces.

### Steps To Reproduce

I open node red editor on my iPad (iOS 14.7.1) in safari, or as installed web app on the homescreen. Opening any flow with the junction node, I am experiencing the above behavior.

### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.0.2
- Node.js version: 18.2.0
- npm version: yarn 1.22.15 / npm 8.9.0
- Platform/OS: Node Red is running on Windows 10 (just in terminal on foreground). 
- Browser: iPad with iOS 14.7.1 using Safari (same on Chrome iOS)

title: Feature: allow icons to be set as dataURIs
body:
(Originally raised on slack)

Currently node/subflow icons have to either be a FA classname, or the name of an icon file provided by the nodes.

It would useful to be able to provide the icon as a base64-encoded data URI (`data:image/svg+xml;base64,....`) that can be inlined in the flow json. That will give more freedom to flow authors without having to manage additional icon files.

There are two parts to this:

1. Allow the `icon` property of a node definition be a data URI.
2. Update the icon chooser UI to allow a value to be pasted in, rather than picking from the list of existing icons.
    - for bonus points, supporting drag-and-drop of a file into the icon chooser to set the property. Would need to think carefully about what file types that should support (SVG only?).

title: Failed to parse JSON string (during export)
body:
When I export data using the node red main menu, using options (local, all flows) and select a folder to export to, the little bar animation for "loading" appears and a long time later - maybe 30sec-60sec later - the files are displayed and simultaneously, a large number of "Failed to parse JSON string" errors are emitted - see screenshot ....

The nodes that generate the errors are MQTT-in nodes but they do not generate this error unless I do the export function.

title: Issue with the TypedInput widget (â€œSelect multiple items from a list of optionsâ€ variant)
body:
### Current Behavior

When using the TypedInput widget in the â€œSelect multiple items from a list of optionsâ€ variant in a custom node and opening the edit page the dropdown has a label with e.g. "4 Selected". If you then open the dropdown and close it the "4 Selected" changes to "0 Selected", eventhough the selected options weren't changed.

### Expected Behavior

I would expect that if you open the dropdown and close it that the text "4 Selected" doesn't change or change according to the number of selected options.

### Steps To Reproduce

I posted the code that I used for a custom node in a Node-RED forum thread:
https://discourse.nodered.org/t/issue-with-the-typedinput-widget-select-multiple-items-from-a-list-of-options-variant/66476

Edit:
It only happens when using integers instead of strings as values in the options array like below:
```

    types: [

            value: "lines",

                { value: 0, label: "Line 0" },

title: Quick-add (typeSearch) closing right after opening
body:
### Current Behavior

When I use ctrl/cmd click in the editor to open the quick-add menu, it shows the menu, but most of the time it immediately closes after I release the mouse button. This results in the quick-add not being usable at all for me, even though it used to work fine in an older version.

### Expected Behavior

The quick-add menu should show on ctrl/cmd click and stay open after releasing the mouse button.

### Steps To Reproduce

The problem seems to be with the loading of the quick-add menu, which somehow blocks the triggering of the mouse up event. I have a fairly large Node-RED project, which might be the reason for this. I (mostly) do not see this on a new installation.

If I debug the issue, it seems that the `canvasMouseUp` event is not getting called immediately after releasing the mouse button, but only after the quick-add menu is completely loaded. So to me it seems to be an issue that the loading of the menu blocks events from coming in, which results in the late delivery of the mouse up event closing the menu.


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.0.2
- Node.js version: 16.16.0
- npm version: 8.11.0
- Platform/OS: Mac OS 12.4
- Browser: Safari 15.5 or Chrome 104.0.5112.79 (although it does not seem browser related)

title: FR: Dynamic Link node enhancement request (backlog item)
body:
_This FR should be considered a backlog item_

Requested several times are various enhancements to the Link Call node... 



1. Timeout error to be optional
2. Default (fall back) target if `msg.target` not found (like the `default:` in a JS `switch` statement)
3. Pass through if target not found
4. make target a typeInput to reduce need for change nodes before each call
 
###  Item 1
The reasoning behind this request is sometimes the user may elect to NOT call the link-out-reply (e.g. filter replies) based on a certain criteria but in doing so an error occurs.
One option here could be to use `0` to mean no timeout.

###  Item 2 + 3
These feature would be additional capabilities and would override the current behaviour. 
An example of the requirement of item 2:  if target "add10" is not found, a default link could be called for alternative processing. 
An example of the requirement of item 3:  if target "add10" is not found, the `msg` should pass through and be routed somewhere else based on the fact it was not processed. 
These 2 features could be added in the form of a dropdown option "Missing Target"...
* Raise error if target not found (same as original)
* Send to fall back target if target not found
* Pass through if target not found

My addition to this would be to add an `error` object to any `msg` that was passed through or was sent to the "fall back" link target so that users can determine what happened to the msg.

### Item 4
A typedInput, defaulted to `msg.target` that permits the user to specify where in the `msg` the target has been provided.

title: Phase out d3
body:
Node-RED has used D3 since day one of its existence. The original structure of the view code was based on a D3 example (can't track down the actual one, but was similar to https://observablehq.com/@d3/force-directed-graph).

Whilst it has remained quite fundamental to how `view.js` works, there is something to be said for phasing out its use. There are optimisations we can make in the code if we aren't having to work in the d3 way.

We're also on an ancient version of d3. Faced with the choice of phasing out its use, or upgrading across multiple major version changes, I want to explore the former.

This PR is a work-in-progress towards that goal.

There are a handful of places where we use d3 for no reason other than it was convenient at the time - and vanilla javascript is more than good enough. That's where I'll start.

title: Context does not persist when switching projects
body:
### Current Behavior

When switching between different projects, Nodered keeps deleting the projects content, so anything set with content.set("ID", 123, "file") gets deleted.

### Expected Behavior

I'd expect the content to be persistent, even when switching between projects.

### Steps To Reproduce

Create a project
Use a node to set the content, i.e. a function node with context.set("ID", 123, "file");
// Under /context a new folder is created
**Either**:
Create a second project
**Or**:
Open another project and deselect "Clear context when switching between projects"

// The previous context is now deleted


### Example flow

```
[{"id":"cc7ba6850f1678f0","type":"tab","label":"Flow 1","disabled":false,"info":"","env":[]},{"id":"bf973ee7e6b9682f","type":"inject","z":"cc7ba6850f1678f0","name":"","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":true,"onceDelay":"1","topic":"","payload":"","payloadType":"date","x":110,"y":120,"wires":[["f48b6e7ceefc1b5e"]]},{"id":"f48b6e7ceefc1b5e","type":"function","z":"cc7ba6850f1678f0","name":"function 1","func":"return msg;","outputs":1,"noerr":0,"initialize":"// Code added here will be run once\n// whenever the node is started.\n context.set(\"ID\", 123, \"file\");","finalize":"","libs":[],"x":280,"y":120,"wires":[[]]}]```

title: feature: Allow user to select more keyboard scopes in keyboard editor
body:
Currently, only `global` and `workspace` are targetable in the keyboard bindings however unde the hood, many more are possible.

this FR proposes to add more user settable scopes via the editor
e.g...
* `edit node`: `red-ui-editor-stack`
* `sidebar`: `red-ui-sidebar-content`

Others should be considered also

NOTES:
the div element used for scope should be focusable to increase chances of being correctly captured. For example, PR #3789 recently added `tabindex="-1"` (`-1` means author must focus the element with [focus()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/focus_event) in response to arrow or other key presses, see [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/Keyboard-navigable_JavaScript_widgets#using_tabindex))

title: Projects generating SSH keys with RSA-SHA which get rejected by server
body:
### Current Behavior

NR Projects feature creates RSA SSH keys signed with SHA 256, Some SSH servers have now been configured to reject all RSA/SHA signed keys (even though SHA256 & SHA512 should still be ok).

https://node-red.slack.com/archives/C1YH60001/p1657845728700159

It presents as just a permission denied to the user

### Expected Behavior

NR generate keys that will work with all git/ssh servers

### Steps To Reproduce

Try and connect to a git server via SSH with a key generated by Node-RED

title: CORS Issue: httpNodeCors options not working correctly when credentials mode set to include in client.
body:
### Current Behavior

Current setting for httpNodeCors:

httpNodeCors: {
       origin: "http://127.0.0.1:3000",
       credentials: true,
       methods: "GET,POST,OPTIONS",
       preflightContinue: false,
       optionsSuccessStatus: 204,
    },

expected Access-Control-Allow-Origin: "http://127.0.0.1:3000"

getting error: Access to XMLHttpRequest at 'https://127.0.0.1:1880/process_login' from origin 'http://127.0.0.1:3000' has been blocked by CORS policy: Response to preflight request doesn't pass access control check: The value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header in the response must not be the wildcard '*' when the request's credentials mode is 'include'. The credentials mode of requests initiated by the XMLHttpRequest is controlled by the withCredentials attribute.

### Expected Behavior

Refer to [specification](https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#cors-protocol-and-credentials)

when credentials mode is include, Access-Control-Allow-Origin:"*" causes the request to fail.

The response from node-red should be in accordance with https://github.com/expressjs/cors#configuration-options

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Enable CORS in node-red.
2. Create a POST Endpoint.
3. Send request from another domain/IP Address/app running on different port with credentials mode set to include.

### Example flow

```
paste your flow here
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 2.2.2
- Node.js version: 16.15.0
- npm version: 8.8.0
- Platform/OS: Windows 10
- Browser: Google Chrome

## Proposed changes
This proposal will open possibility to display custom tooltips to all nodes. This can be used to for example give a quick explanation about what the node does without having to open it.

title: Subflow editor alignment issues
Text Undo/Redo does not work after clicking expand button
body:
### Current Behavior

When expanding the edit window of a node that allows multi-line text entry (function node) the undo/redo buffer is flushed.
 
I am guessing that when expanding you are creating a new textbox and destroying the current one copying the existing text from one to the other. 

### Expected Behavior

The Undo/Redo buffer should follow expansion 

### Steps To Reproduce

Add a `function` node to a page.
Double-click node to open the editor pane
Write some text
Perform some undo/redo operations to ensure it works
Click the `Expand` button top-right of editor window
Perform some undo/redo operations again, they no longer work for previous text entry 

### Example flow

N/A

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 3.0.0 b2 (also happens in v2.2.2 so not a newly created bug)
- Node.js version: 18.1
- npm version: 8.8.0
- Platform/OS: Linux 5.13.0-41-generic x86_64
- Browser: Firefox 100

title: Some keyboard shortcuts not working after reload
body:
### Current Behavior

Custom key mappings for `ctrl-up` and `ctrl-down` do not work after reloading the editor. Instead, they map to the default usage of moving a node up and down on the editor workspace.

### Expected Behavior

After reloading the editor in the browser, my custom key mappings for `ctrl-up` and `ctrl-down` should work as I specified in the keyboard shortcut editor.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Set up the following keyboard shortcuts using the user settings file or in the editor UI:
```
{
 "core:enable-flow": {
   "scope": "*",
   "key": "ctrl-shift-up"
 },
 "core:disable-selected-nodes": {
   "scope": "*",
   "key": "ctrl-down"
 },
 "core:disable-flow": {
   "scope": "*",
   "key": "ctrl-shift-down"
 },
 "core:enable-selected-nodes": {
   "scope": "*",
   "key": "ctrl-up"
 }
}
```

2. Reload the editor

3. Attempt to use the `ctrl-up` and `ctrl-down` keyboard shortcuts to enable/disable the selected node, per the custom mapping above.

(Note: This example also shows custom keyboard shortcuts for `ctrl-shift-up` and `ctrl-shift-down`, which do **not** have the issue reported here. This is done to help understand where the issue might be.)

### Example flow

N/A

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 2.2.2
- Node.js version: 16.13.1
- npm version: 8.1.2
- Platform/OS: Windows + Raspbian Pi OS (tried on both OSs, all other versions the same)
- Browser: Chrome 101

title: Local Filesystem Context Store does not persist Map and Set objects
body:
### Current Behavior

When nodered is configure to persist the context in the local filesystem, Map and Set objects are not persisted but replaced by empty objects.

It's most likely because the local file system persistent module uses `JSON.stringify` and `JSON.parse`, which does not persist correctly Maps and Sets. `JSON.stringify(new Map([['test', 1234]])) => "{}"`

### Expected Behavior

Map and Set could be persisted correctly. Or a warning message could be displayed.

### Steps To Reproduce

1:  Configure NodeRed to use the local filesystem to persist the context

```js
     contextStorage: {
         default: {
             module:"localfilesystem"
         },
     },
```

2. Create a Map, or a Set, and persist it in the context.
3. Restart nodered, it is now an empty object.

You can test the example flow, click inject once to create a map and an object to persist them. Click once more to see their correct value in the debug log. Restart NodeRed and click inject to see the map being transformed into an empty object.

### Example flow

```
[

        "id": "8382b5f1f3f311af",
        "type": "tab",
        "label": "localfilesystem and Map",
        "disabled": false,
        "info": "",
        "env": []
    },
    {
        "id": "97cdcb618f98ea58",
        "type": "inject",
        "z": "8382b5f1f3f311af",
        "name": "",
        "props": [
            {
                "p": "map",
                "v": "map",
                "vt": "flow"
            },
            {
                "p": "object",
                "v": "object",
                "vt": "flow"
            }
        ],
        "repeat": "",
        "crontab": "",
        "once": false,
        "onceDelay": 0.1,
        "topic": "",
        "x": 190,
        "y": 240,
        "wires": [
            [
                "0966b8a3a5f7875d"
            ]
        ]
    },
    {
        "id": "744140185f93851b",
        "type": "debug",
        "z": "8382b5f1f3f311af",
        "name": "",
        "active": true,
        "tosidebar": true,
        "console": false,
        "tostatus": false,
        "complete": "true",
        "targetType": "full",
        "statusVal": "",
        "statusType": "auto",
        "x": 530,

        "wires": []
    },
    {
        "id": "0966b8a3a5f7875d",

            {

title: Upgrade to FontAwesome 6
body: This is a first pass at updating to FA6 - which now provides backwards compatibility to FA4 (which FA5 did not). Whilst updating to their latest will bring a larger selection of built-in icons, there are downsides to doing this. FontAwesome now license their icon collections. There is a Free tier we could stick with. However, this only includes the 'solid' icon style - it doesn't include the 'regular' style which is closer in appearance to what we had in with FA4. It makes the icons look a bit chunkier. - FontAwesome 4 - FontAwesome 6 We could look at purchasing a license via the OpenJS Foundation - however it isn't clear what the licensing implications are when it comes to a project like NR where 3rd parties embed and commercialise it for themselves. If we do decide to go with FA6-free, then some further work is needed in the editor: - update the font-awesome.js list of icon names used to build the icon picker dialog - update the code that positions a node icon when provided by FA - the alignment has changed with this upgrade - more thorough testing through the whole UI to check for any icons that need refining

title: Use of unknown context store in function node, error doesn't ref node
body:
### Current Behavior

The use of an unknown context store in a function node generates a warning (should it be an error?) which does not indicate the node where the error exists. For example, in a Function node, the line
let x = context.get("x","31")
Shows

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38307/158057746-299b2c8a-6653-4eb2-b4db-2c801f2d7b8e.png)

So it can be difficult to determine where the fault lies.

### Expected Behavior

The error should ideally include information to identify the node.

### Steps To Reproduce

See above

### Example flow

title: Additional Http methods
body:
fixes #3422

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)


## Proposed changes

Adds the following methods to the HTTP In node...

### HEAD
The HEAD method asks for a response identical to a GET request, but without the response body.

### OPTIONS
The OPTIONS method describes the communication options for the target resource.

### TRACE
The TRACE method performs a message loop-back test along the path to the target resource.


### NOTES
* the CONNECT method was not included - was difficult to justify (no use case)
* NR already handles OPTIONS method for "*" for the CORS settings - which means adding OPTIONS HTTP-In nodes were not handled. The was overcame by checking which routes are setup for OPTIONS method within the `options` handler & calling `next()` or `corsHandler` appropriately
  * Users can remove the `httpNodeCors` from settings.js altogether and manage this via setting up endpoints on each route for OPTIONS
  * Users can override individual routes by adding OPTIONS endpoints on desired routes


## Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [x] For non-bugfix PRs, I have discussed this change on the forum/slack team.
- [x] I have run `grunt` to verify the unit tests pass
- [ ] I have added suitable unit tests to cover the new/changed functionality

title: Theme not applied on startup on Chrome, Cannot GET /theme/css/theme.min.css
body:
### Current Behavior

Chrome does not use specified theme on opening browser after node-red restart if the editor is already open in a browser tab.

### Expected Behavior

Theme should be used.

### Steps To Reproduce

Close the browser (Chrome) with the editor open in a tab
Restart node-red
Open the browser

The editor appears but the theme is not applied, the default theme appears to be used.
The browser console shows

Refused to apply style from 'http://localhost:1880/theme/css/theme.min.css' because its MIME type ('text/html') is not a supported stylesheet MIME type, and strict MIME checking is enabled.
:1880/#flow/bdd7be38.d3b55:1 Refused to apply style from 'http://localhost:1880/theme/css/theme-customizations.min.css' because its MIME type ('text/html') is not a supported stylesheet MIME type, and strict MIME checking is enabled.
To get the theme applied refresh the browser page.
Once the page has been refreshed then there is no further problem. The browser may be closed and opened and the theme continues to be used. To see the problem node-red must be restarted and the browser opened.

I believe the problem is that if node-red is restarted and then http://localhost:1880/theme/css/theme.min.css is entered into the browser window the response is
Cannot GET /theme/css/theme.min.css
If the node-red editor page is then refreshed then that url shows the theme as expected.

The problem is not seen with Firefox so I guess it is a timing issue to do with when the theme css becomes available.


### Example flow

_No response_

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 2.2.2
- Node.js version: 16.14.0
- npm version:
- Platform/OS: Ubuntu on laptop
- Browser: Chrome 99.0.4844.51

Tested with "midnight-red" 2.2.0 and with "dark"

title: Keyboard binding issue
body:
### Current Behaviour


Assigning  <kbd>CTRL-Enter</kbd>  while already assigned to another shortcut (with different scope) gets stored but clearing the default shortcut ( <kbd>CTRL-Enter</kbd>) for "core:go-to-selection" clears the newly assigned "Deploy" shortcut as well. 


### Expected Behaviour

Removing <kbd>CTRL-Enter</kbd>(with workspace scope) should not remove shortcut <kbd>CTRL-Enter</kbd> (with global scope, assigned to other action)

### Steps To Reproduce

#### Key binding issue...
1. Assign <kbd>CTRL-Enter</kbd> to Deploy action (with workspace scope)
    1.  at this point, <kbd>CTRL-Enter</kbd> should be assigned to both "Deploy flows" and "Confirm Edit Tray"
2. Close User Settings
3. Re-open User Settings
4. Clear the shoutcut from  **"Confirm Edit Tray"**
5. Close User Settings
6. Re-open User Settings

Note now **"Deploy Flows"** has no shortcut and **"Confirm Edit Tray"** shortcut is back.

- Node.js version: 16
- npm version: NA
- Platform/OS: Windows

title: Don't unsubscribe MQTT Level 1 or above topics on nodered restart / close or at least add option
body:
### Current Behavior

I use MQTT a lot. MQTT has with Level 1 the ability that no messages are lost and every message is processed. I process them via Node
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37013344/154585011-3d9f0f37-541c-4756-bbe1-9a174ab916e5.png) and settings
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37013344/154585112-6f0dca82-f5fc-4b29-b0b6-13c93c264ff8.png)

Multiple clients publish to Topic "queuedInput". If there is a power outage everything works fine, all messages are processed as they should.
If I reboot the system for updates nodered shuts down gracefully it unsubscribes that topic. That means all messages are lost in between the reboot time which is not what it should be.


You can see that all topics are unsubscribed on Node close in https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/fcf299401555e4ee02241999bb42fca80a1634b2/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/10-mqtt.js#L1066

### Expected Behavior

When using MQTT Level 1 and above and don't using clean session MQTT Node should not unsubscribe from those topics, so messages are queued in the MQTT broker as intended.

### Steps To Reproduce

Set up an MQTT-In Node with MQTT level 1, disabled clean session and client id. Publish data like an incrementing number every second and process it by writing to a file. 

Cut power of Node-RED system, wait a bit, then restart the system. Watch your file, all messages will be inside.

Now reboot the system, messages will be lost beginning with the reboot.

### Example flow

I think I've made the issue quite clear. If you really need full example codes, please tell, then I'll create some.

```
paste your flow here
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: v2.1.4
- Node.js version: v12.22.10

The rest shouldn't matter. Even if this install is an older version, node close behaviour in the source code is the same as the current in https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/fcf299401555e4ee02241999bb42fca80a1634b2/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/10-mqtt.js#L1066

title: feature: Add a pause button to the Debug sidebar
body:
This has been on the backlog for a long time.

There are some ux challenges around pausing the debug sidebar as we automatically prune messages once the limit has been reached. We would need to resolve what to do if the sidebar is left paused and the backlog gets to a point where the current messages need to be pruned.

https://discourse.nodered.org/t/feature-request-pause-debug-panel/58057

title: feature: Store sidebar width between editor sessions
body:
### Description

Add to the zoom/location options

title: feature: Switch: support compound AND/OR rules
body:
### Description

Reduce the need to make tangle nests of switch nodes

title: feature: Link nodes: make the list of target link nodes more accessible
body:
### Description

The long list can make it hard to find the desired target.

title: feature: File Out: add option to specify file permissions of created file
body:
### Description

Will need the appropriate error handling if permissions were not set properly

title: feature: Debug: add 'copy value' tools at the array slice level
body:
### Description

The debug sidebar displays arrays in slices of 10 items. It would be useful to be able to copy a whole slice, rather than just individual values.

title: feature: HTTP Response: support sending fragmented responses
body:
### Description

The current HTTP response node only allows a single response. It would be useful to support sending a full message sequence as a chunked response - such as streaming a large response rather than having to format it into a single large message.

title: feature: HTML: add option to handle fragments rather than whole docs
body:
### Description

The change in html parsing lib meant some edge cases around html fragments became harder to handle automagically. We'll need an explicit option added to handle fragments.

title: feature: HTTP In: support other methods such as Options
body:
### Description

We currently only support the main four methods - need to broaded that out

title: feature: Allow credentials to be marked as required as part of validation
body:
### Description

Currently a node doesn't validate credentials. The slight challenge is we don't have the true credential values in the editor - if fact, we only load the credential meta-data when editing a node for the first time. But we should be able to know if they exist or not.

title: feature: Add 'selection to link call flow' action
body:
### Description

Similar to the 'convert to subflow' action, but doing it with link call flow. A particular challenge is where to place the moved nodes.

title: feature: Allow nodes to be deselected in Export dialog
body:
### Description

This will help users to customise what is exported, for example, leaving behind config nodes or subflow definitions.

title: feature: Organise subflows by category in Help sidebar
body:
### Description

The subflows are currently listed in their natural order in a single list. As they can be assigned to custom categories, it would be more useful to have the Help sidebar list to reflect that hierarchy.

title: Support Mustache path in copy button on debug tab
body: - [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ## Proposed changes I tried to implement the copy button enhancement which we discussed on [the Node-RED forum](https://discourse.nodered.org/t/support-bracket-name-to-specify-array-index-in-mustache/57585/6). title: node red restarts when some nodes are triggered with descriptive error.
body:
### Current Behavior

running node red along with home assistant. Everything was working fine until a few weeks ago.
seemingly random events from multiple nodes are triggering node red to restart with the same error message.

### Expected Behavior

no restarts...

### Steps To Reproduce

hard to say..  


### Example flow

log:
```
6 Jan 12:22:17 - [red] Uncaught Exception:
6 Jan 12:22:17 - [error] TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'log')
    at log_helper (/opt/node_modules/@node-red/runtime/lib/nodes/Node.js:499:16)
    at Node.warn (/opt/node_modules/@node-red/runtime/lib/nodes/Node.js:512:5)
    at runMicrotasks (<anonymous>)
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:96:5)
[12:22:17] INFO: Starting Node-RED...
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 2.1.4

title: Link arrow heads and disconnected ports
body: - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) This is a work in progress. Sharing to get early feedback. Two occasion requests we get are: - add arrow heads to the wires to help indicate direction of flows - visually distinguish between connected and disconnected node ports This PR implements both of these things. - The unconnected ports are slightly lighter. I've tried various combinations of lightness/dotted border and can't decide yet what looks right. For example: - The arrow heads are currently hardcoded in. Before this PR merges, there will be an option to enable them via `editorTheme` in settings.js.

title: HTTP/2 client requests home page or http interface no response
body:
### Current Behavior

When the following request headers are included, the node-red server does not respond:

```
Connection: Upgrade, HTTP2-Settings
Upgrade: h2c
HTTP2-Settings: AAMAAABkAAQCAAAAAAIAAAAA
```

### Expected Behavior

It should be compatible and respond to http/1.1 protocol results normally.

### Steps To Reproduce

Any http client request with the above request header will not respond normally.

### Example flow

```js
const axios = require("axios")
axios.get("http://localhost:1880", {
  headers: {
    Connection: "Upgrade, HTTP2-Settings",
    Upgrade: "h2c"
  }
}).then(res => {
  console.log(res.status, res.data)
}).catch(err => {
  console.log(err)
})
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: v2.1.4
- Node.js version: v16.13.1
- npm version: v8.2.0
- Platform/OS: Windows Locally or Docker
- Browser: None

title: set node width dependent on gridsize
body:
(up to 50 - then use half sizes or quarters etc)

<!--
## Before you hit that Submit button....

Please read our [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
before submitting a pull-request.

## Types of changes

What types of changes does your code introduce?
Put an `x` in the boxes that apply
-->

- [x] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

<!--
If you want to raise a pull-request with a new feature, or a refactoring
of existing code, it **may well get rejected** if it hasn't been discussed on
the [forum](https://discourse.nodered.org) or
[slack team](https://nodered.org/slack) first.

-->

## Proposed changes

<!-- Describe the nature of this change. What problem does it address? -->

In order to better help users OCD this PR helps align the right hand side of nodes with the current grid size so both sides are aligned... - but only up to a grid size of 50 (which is quite large - default is 20).... above 50 it uses the grid size/2  (and above 100 it uses grid size/4 etc - so will give half and quarter increments rather than just make massive nodes.

title: Saving huge array in global context on localfilesystem crashes node red
body:
### Current Behavior

The first Inject in the attached flow creates a 0.5GB array of objects in localfilesystem global context.  Upon running it, when node red attempts to flush it to disc, it hogs the processor for several minutes (presumably attempting to build the JSON), and then crashes with
```
8 Nov 16:45:46 - [red] Uncaught Exception:
8 Nov 16:45:46 - [error] RangeError: Invalid string length
    at JSON.stringify (<anonymous>)
    at stringify (/usr/lib/node_modules/node-red/node_modules/json-stringify-safe/stringify.js:5:15)
    at stringify (/usr/lib/node_modules/node-red/node_modules/@node-red/runtime/lib/nodes/context/localfilesystem.js:136:18)
    at /usr/lib/node_modules/node-red/node_modules/@node-red/runtime/lib/nodes/context/localfilesystem.js:214:46
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at LocalFileSystem.self._flushPendingWrites (/usr/lib/node_modules/node-red/node_modules/@node-red/runtime/lib/nodes/context/localfilesystem.js:211:24)
    at /usr/lib/node_modules/node-red/node_modules/@node-red/runtime/lib/nodes/context/localfilesystem.js:307:53
```
The second inject creates a small array with the same structure and works correctly.

### Expected Behavior

Either it should work correctly, or it should fail with an appropriate error, rather than crash node-red.

### Steps To Reproduce

See above

### Example flow

```
[{"id":"cecf7c5af47399f3","type":"function","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"Big Data","func":"let data = global.get(\"data\", \"file\")\nlet bigBuffer = {time: msg.payload, buffer: Buffer.alloc(100000)}\nif (typeof data === \"undefined\") {\n    node.warn(\"undefined\")\n    data = Array(5000).fill(bigBuffer, 0);\n}\nglobal.set(\"data\", data, \"file\")\nreturn msg;","outputs":1,"noerr":0,"initialize":"","finalize":"","libs":[],"x":350,"y":1160,"wires":[["9357c2ae0507e87f"]]},{"id":"48ce64f2ea702719","type":"inject","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"","payload":"","payloadType":"date","x":170,"y":1160,"wires":[["cecf7c5af47399f3"]]},{"id":"9357c2ae0507e87f","type":"debug","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"","active":true,"tosidebar":true,"console":false,"tostatus":false,"complete":"false","statusVal":"","statusType":"auto","x":560,"y":1160,"wires":[]},{"id":"16adf19296938514","type":"function","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"Little Data","func":"let data = global.get(\"ldata\", \"file\")\nlet bigBuffer = {time: msg.payload, buffer: Buffer.alloc(2)}\nif (typeof data === \"undefined\") {\n    data = Array(5).fill(bigBuffer, 0);\n}\nglobal.set(\"ldata\", data, \"file\")\nreturn msg;","outputs":1,"noerr":0,"initialize":"","finalize":"","libs":[],"x":320,"y":1300,"wires":[["47767708860e7247"]]},{"id":"17d1722c0d37f72c","type":"inject","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"","props":[{"p":"payload"},{"p":"topic","vt":"str"}],"repeat":"","crontab":"","once":false,"onceDelay":0.1,"topic":"","payload":"","payloadType":"date","x":160,"y":1300,"wires":[["16adf19296938514"]]},{"id":"47767708860e7247","type":"debug","z":"bdd7be38.d3b55","name":"","active":true,"tosidebar":true,"console":false,"tostatus":false,"complete":"false","statusVal":"","statusType":"auto","x":510,"y":1300,"wires":[]}]
```


### Environment

- Node.js version: 16.13.0

- Platform/OS: i5 laptop, Ubuntu 20.04
- Browser: Firefox

title: Fail to checkout a remote git branch in project
body:
### Current Behavior

I'm using the project mode in Node-RED, and working in a large team.
I want to checkout a remote branch from the "Commit History" panel or the editor in order to make code review or update Merge Request in GitLab. When I type the name of the remote branch, the branch is not found. The only possibility is to create a local branch.

Creating a local branch with same name is not a solution because the parent node of the branch will not be identical that the remote one and will create lot's of conflicts.

Bug was also posted in the community: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/how-to-checkout-a-remote-git-branch-using-history-panel/52263

### Expected Behavior

When looking for local branch in the "History" panel, the remote branches should be proposed to checkout.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create branch in the remote repository
2. Go to "Commit History" panel in editor
3. Try to checkout the remote branch

### Example flow

![node-red-commit-history](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25277953/138843019-5e080980-b1ae-4b3d-914c-f5a3e61d99aa.png)

### Environment

- Node-RED version: 1.3.6
- Node.js version: v10.24.1
- npm version: 6.14.12
- Platform/OS: docker/linux
- Browser: Firefox

title: Streams not separated
body:
### Current Behavior

Hi,

IÂ´m currently experiencing an unwanted behavior in Node-RED where a stream which got separated in two separate streams and subsequently treated by subflows still reference each other.
The following screenshot might be better in explaining the situation than I am able to:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/79642261/138725112-18733223-0b7b-4c16-905a-1ba5e3efb232.png)

Even though the stream splits up and gets handled by two different subflows, they end up with the same message id when being output to the debug window, as can be seen in the screenshot. Critically, they both wrongfully have the same output. If I remove one of the subflows, the remaining one works correctly again.

At this point I am at a loss to what I am doing wrong. Is this expected behavior of subflows?

### Expected Behavior

a stream which gets split up in multiple streams now has a copy of the former message in each stream.

### Steps To Reproduce

Not sure, maybe has to do with subflows?

### Example flow

```
paste your flow here
```


### Environment

- Node-RED version: 2.0.6
- Node.js version:
- npm version:
- Platform/OS: Raspberry Pi 4/ Hass OS
- Browser: MS Edge

title: Web socket timeout for "Listen on"
body:
https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/1419729458b8423484e70c64fb7f762c6ff6a1ca/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/22-websocket.js#L186-L198

This would be a neat feature to have.

I tested it with a hardcoded timeout of 30000 ms and it works well for me if i also remove the 
`clearInterval(node.heartbeatInterval);` calls.

https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/1419729458b8423484e70c64fb7f762c6ff6a1ca/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/22-websocket.js#L128
https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/1419729458b8423484e70c64fb7f762c6ff6a1ca/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/22-websocket.js#L144

The node already has a property called heartbeat which is only used for "Connect to" nodes
I Think he same property could be used for "Listen On" nodes as well

It would require a little bit of copy&pasting from here:
https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/1419729458b8423484e70c64fb7f762c6ff6a1ca/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/22-websocket.html#L193-L201

title: Subflow instances do not get triggered when deploying modified flows
body:
### Current Behavior

Self emitting subflow instances (inject once...) do not get triggered when the nodes are duplicated, only the latest copy emits when the deploy option is set to modified flows.

This also applies to newly added link in/out nodes when connected to those nodes, nothing gets triggered in that case (separate issue ?) 

### Expected Behavior

All self injecting subflow  instances should emit their `msg` upon deploy modified flows.

### Steps To Reproduce

Create a new subflow.
Add an inject node, enable checkbox "inject once" after 0.1s
Connect it to the output node.

Add subflow to new flow
Add debug node.
Connect the 2 together
Set deploy to modified flows.

Deploy: output is a timestamp
copy/paste the nodes
Deploy: output is a single timestamp, only from the latest instance.

### Example flow

title: Correlation log for precise message tracing on Join/Split node
body:
- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

## Proposed changes

For precise tracing for nodes which splitting or joining the messages, these nodes should emit a correlation log to provide information of which message is depend on another message.
This PR add a new `correlate` metric event to Join/Split node.

For detailed information, see [design note](https://github.com/node-red/designs/blob/c6687c8ab5d04e6c6eaafee23910b8cda82fecf1/designs/message-trace/README.md) (not yet merged).

body:
<!--

before submitting a pull-request.

What types of changes does your code introduce?

-->

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

<!--
If you want to raise a pull-request with a new feature, or a refactoring
of existing code, it **may well get rejected** if it hasn't been discussed on
the [forum](https://discourse.nodered.org) or
[slack team](https://nodered.org/slack) first.

-->

## Proposed changes
This adds the ability to control the deploy process from the editor using client-side editor hooks API.

###Example of using
```javascript
RED.hooks.add("preDeploy",  (event, done) => {
    setTimeout(() => {
        console.log('preDeploy client hook');
        console.log(event);
        done(false);// Cancel deploy
    }, 2000)
});

RED.hooks.add("postDeploy",  (event, done) => {
    console.log('postDeploy client hook');
    console.log(event);
    done();
});
```

<!-- Describe the nature of this change. What problem does it address? -->

title: UDP In node stops receiving multicast data after 4 Minutes if attached to a IGMP active Switch
body:
<!--
This issue tracker is for problems with the Node-RED runtime, the editor or the core nodes.

If your issue is:
  - a general 'how-to' type question,
  - a feature request or suggestion for a change,
  - or problems with 3rd party (`node-red-contrib-`) nodes

please use the [Node-RED Forum](https://discourse.nodered.org) or [slack team](https://nodered.org/slack).

You could also consider asking a question on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/node-red) and tag it `node-red`.

That way the whole Node-RED user community can help, rather than rely on the core development team.

To help us understand the issue, please fill-in as much of the following information as you can:
-->

### What are the steps to reproduce?
Attach a device with Node-Red (Client) installed to a Switch which performs IGMP management.
Set Up a UDP Multicast Server on another (Server) and attach it to the switch, let it send multicast messages to group. (e.g. 239.12.255.254)
Create a Flow in Node-Red triggered by node "UDP IN" set Listen for to "Multicast messages" add IP4 into Group (e.g. 239.12.255.254)
Activate IGMP management on the switch.

### What happens?
Flow will perform perfectly and stop working after approx. 4 minutes.

### What do you expect to happen?
Flow to continue working without stopping

### Workaround
- [ ] Turn of IGMP management in switch. UDP IN NODE should start receiving data immediately. 

### Possible Solution
- [ ] If multicast messages is selected and group has been added the client should send join request with the group after 4 minutes to update the switch's database that client is still listening and route for multicast package is sill required.
(similar to #3056)

### related Wikipedia Links
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IGMP_snooping

### Please tell us about your environment:
Server - Energy Meter
Client - Raspberry Pi
Switch NetGear JGS524E â€“ 24-Port Gigabit Ethernet Plus Switch
- [ ] Node-RED version: 1.2.9 / RedMatic Version 7.2.1
- [ ] Node.js version: v12.22.1
- [ ] npm version: 6.14.12
- [ ] Platform/OS: Raspberry Pi/Redmatic

title: Problem using more nodes/expanding nodes (currently 47 nodes)
body:
<!--
## Before you hit that Submit button....

This issue tracker is for problems with the Node-RED runtime, the editor or the core nodes.

If your issue is:
  - a general 'how-to' type question,

That way the whole Node-RED user community can help, rather than rely on the core development team.

## So you have a real issue to raise...

To help us understand the issue, please fill-in as much of the following information as you can:
-->

### What are the steps to reproduce?
I am using Node Red for a year now, without any problems. I have about 12 flows, since I am working on my latest flow I receive the message "Deploy failed: no response from server", when I deploy the configuration. I did some further testing and I now figured out that when I remove one node from any other flows, I can add one node to any flow, when I then hit deploy, the configuration is "Successfully deployed". If I want to add two nodes, then I have to remove two nodes somewhere else. On advise of someone on noderedforum, I already increased the "apiMaxLength" to 10mb and 100mb, without results.

### What happens?
When I add one node to a flow and I hit the deploy button, I receive the mssage "Deploy failed: no response from server". When I remove one node (does not matter which one), I receive "Successfully deployed" when I hit the deployment button.

### What do you expect to happen?
I expect that I can extend with more nodes. I am using only default nodes, with one custom node (used once). I am now using 47 nodes in total. I also removed the custom node, but same problem.

### Please tell us about your environment:

- [ ] Node-RED version: 1.3.5
- [ ] Node.js version:
- [ ] npm version:
- [ ] Platform/OS: Debian 10.9
- [ ] Browser: Chrome
- [ ] running in Docker: Yes

title: Custom Middleware: 'httpAdminMiddleware' is added to 'HTTP In' nodes and Node-RED dashboard
body:
We're trying to use the custom middleware `httpAdminMiddleware`, `httpNodeMiddleware` and the middleware for the Node-RED dashboard (set in property `ui` in settings.js) for authorization based on a header that is set by a reverse-proxy. (We check whether the user has the required role.) Yet the `httpAdminMiddleware` is added to all routes and not just to the admin/editor routes as we would expect from reading the user-guide.

### What are the steps to reproduce?

- Add `httpAdminMiddleware` to setting.js
- Add an `http in` node to a flow and deploy it
- Install the node-red-dashboard

### What happens?
- The middleware configured in `httpAdminMiddleware` is added for all requests to the `http in` node and requests to the dashboard (/ui)

### What do you expect to happen?
We would expect the `httpAdminMiddleware` to only be added to admin/editor routes.

### Please tell us about your environment:

- [x] Node-RED version: 1.2.9
- [x] Node.js version: 10.23.2
- [x] npm version: 6.14.10
- [x] Platform/OS: Docker on Windows
- [x] Browser: Chrome

title: MQTT-Node: Messages are lost on connection problems, despite QOS-Level 1
body:
<!--
This issue tracker is for problems with the Node-RED runtime, the editor or the core nodes.

If your issue is:
  - a general 'how-to' type question,
  - a feature request or suggestion for a change,
  - or problems with 3rd party (`node-red-contrib-`) nodes

please use the [Node-RED Forum](https://discourse.nodered.org) or [slack team](https://nodered.org/slack).

You could also consider asking a question on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/node-red) and tag it `node-red`.

That way the whole Node-RED user community can help, rather than rely on the core development team.

To help us understand the issue, please fill-in as much of the following information as you can:
-->

### What are the steps to reproduce?
Generate this simple testflow
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37013344/107162181-bd35c180-69a1-11eb-9c9d-5370dfa26767.png)
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37013344/107162185-ce7ece00-69a1-11eb-8e74-1ccf8056b693.png)
Subscripe topic on another machine via
`mosquitto_sub -h <MQTT Server-Address> -t /testtopic -q 1`

In the following 0;19 means 0am and 19 minutes. Thats just for better redoing the steps.

0:19 Click inject. You'll see that you receive the timestamp.

0:20 On NodeRed host do
`sudo iptables -A OUTPUT -d <IP of MQTT Server>/32 -j DROP` to simulate network problems.
Click 5 times inject node.

Wait until MQTT Node shows connections problems
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37013344/107162283-5cf34f80-69a2-11eb-8f72-8e9ded642efa.png)

0:21 click 5 times inject node

0:22 do `sudo iptables -D OUTPUT -d <IP of MQTT Server>/32 -j DROP` to reestablish connection.
Don't wait. Immediately after executing that command click inject Node 5 times.


### What happens?

MQTT Client shows

```
1612739965989 --> 0:19
1612740005045 --> 0:20
1612740006033 --> 0:20
1612740006913 --> 0:20
1612740007707 --> 0:20
1612740008476 --> 0:20
```
So a lot of messages are lost. It seems all messages are lost that are received while not in connected state.


### What do you expect to happen?

I expected that all messages are received. Maybe duplicate because of QOS1, but definitely no dropped messages.
Or if dropped messages, then there should be thrown an error with you can catch by a Catch-Node.

### Please tell us about your environment:

- [x] Node-RED version: v1.2.6
- [x] Node.js version: v12.20.0
- [ ] npm version:
- [x] Platform/OS: Linux 5.4.79-v7l+ arm LE
- [x] Browser: Firefox

title: Cannot use Admin and Dashboard the same time on Safari (MacOS and iOS)
body:
### What are the steps to reproduce?
- Using Safari on MacOS or IOS
- Open dashboard with basic authentication on Safari
- Open admin in another tab, enter username and pass. Now you cannot login although input right authentication info
### What happens?

Cannot login admin after using httpNodeAuth on ios

### What do you expect to happen?
Admin must be authorized
### Please tell us about your environment:

- [ ] Node-RED version: 1.2.1
- [ ] Node.js version: 12.16.1
- [ ] npm version: 6.13.4
- [ ] Platform/OS: MacOS BigSur and iOS 13.5.1 
- [ ] Browser: Safari

### Suggest solution

From my research, this is the behavior of Safari. In a domain, if we use Basic Auth, Safari will modify all header request to basic auth; that mean clear out the Bearer Token of Node Red admin, that force user to login page

Therefore, we cannot do anything to solve this problem except remove basicAuth from Node-RED and change to another authorization method like JWT or Middleware auth for Dashboard

title: open dashboard in browser crashes node-red when computer wakes up after sleep
body:
### What are the steps to reproduce?
1.) open node-red dashboard in browser and leave it open
2.) send computer (a Mac in my case) to sleep
3.) wake up computer after some time (in my case i send the mac to sleep in the evening and wake it up in the morning)


### What happens?
node-red crashes

### What do you expect to happen?
node-red NOT crashing. The dashboard crashing/restarting would be ok-ish.

### Please tell us about your environment:

- [ ] Node-RED version:  1.2.7
- [ ] Node.js version: 10.23.1
- [ ] npm version: 6.14.10
- [ ] Platform/OS: x64 debian 10
- [ ] Browser: Firefox 84.0.2
